questions.text: A 10-day-old male infant is brought by the parents with a history of poor feeding and recurrent generalized convulsions. On examination, the pediatrician notices repetitive movements of the extremities which appear like boxing and bicycling movements. A peculiar burnt sugar odor of urine was noted and urine was positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Poor feeding, convulsions, and characteristic boxing-bicycling movements with a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test point to the diagnosis of Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). The peculiar burnt sugar odor of urine is characteristic of this disease.

Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids (BCAA). Their decarboxylation is accomplished by branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDH) using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme. MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of BCKDH. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and their corresponding α-keto acids accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain. The patient excretes these ketoacids in the urine which will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Leucine is now metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to α-ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine, alanine, and aspartate). α-Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. It may clinically manifest as encephalopathy and brain edema known as leucinosis. The disease presents as poor feeding and vomiting on the first few days of life and may progress to lethargy and coma. Examination reveals periods of hypertonicity that alternate with bouts of flaccidity. This appears as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements of the extremities. Convulsions occur in most infants.

Treatment options include restricting dietary substances and supplementing with thiamine for milder forms. Hemodialysis is considered in critically ill cases.

Other options:

Option B: Phenylketonuria (PKU) results from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It manifests as a progressive intellectual disability. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation and a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Option C: Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition due to a deficiency of the enzyme 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase which catalyzes the reaction of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisic acid in the tyrosine catabolism pathway. It leads to the accumulation of the metabolite hawkinsin. Most of the patients present during the weaning period with features of persistent metabolic acidosis and failure to thrive. The swimming pool odor of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

Option D:  Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odor.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complains of pain in the right hip following a fall from her bed. On examination, the limb was shortened and in external rotation. X-ray was performed which showed an unstable inter-trochanteric fracture of the right femur. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Unstable inter-trochanteric fractures are best treated with intramedullary implants like a proximal femoral nail.

The intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by intramedullary and extramedullary implants.

  • Intramedullary implants include proximal femoral nail and gamma nail which are used in displaced/unstable intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. Compared to dynamic hip screws, the intramedullary fixation with proximal femoral nails has smaller incisions, decreased blood loss, decreased femoral neck shortening, and decreased risk of infection.
  • Extramedullary implants include a dynamic hip screw which is used in undisplaced/stable inter-trochanteric fractures

The below image shows the proximal femoral nail with locking and stabilization screws.

Below image shows the dynamic hip screw. It has a long cancellous screw which glides freely inside the sleeve of the side plate.

Inter-trochanteric fracture

Fractures in the inter-trochanteric region of the proximal femur, involving either the greater or the lesser trochanter or both, are grouped in this category. In the elderly, the fracture is normally sustained by a sideway fall or a blow over the greater trochanter. In the young, it occurs following violent trauma, as in a road traffic accident.

Clinical features include a history of a fall or road accident, followed by pain in the region of the groin and an inability to move the leg. There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be short and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter.

X-ray of an inter-trochanteric fracture

Complications include malunion and osteoarhtritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents with a sudden onset stabbing pain followed by diffuse abdominal pain and distension. He has a history of burning epigastric pain that is relieved by eating, and nocturnal pain for the past 5 months. His abdominal X-ray is as shown below. Which among the following is not associated with the pathology depicted in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain and distension and erect x-ray showing air under the diaphragm is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum due to duodenal perforation. Spinnaker sail sign is not seen in pneumoperitoneum.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.

The other signs mentioned above are seen in the pneumoperitoneum caused due to hollow viscus perforation.

Duodenal perforation characterized by a sudden, sharp, stabbing pain is a known complication of peptic ulcer disease suggested by this patient’s history. The erect X-ray in pneumoperitoneum shows gas under the diaphragm. Other signs can be further divided into anatomical compartments in relation to the pneumoperitoneum:

Bowel related signs-

  • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign or bas-relief sign) - 50% of the cases have gas in the right upper quadrant adjacent to the liver, lying mainly in the subhepatic space and the hepatorenal fossa (Morrison’s pouch). When both the outer and inner walls of a bowel loop are visualized, it is known as Rigler’s sign.
  • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign) - The formation of a radiolucent triangle of gas around three bowel loops or two bowel loops and the abdominal wall. 

Peritoneal ligament related signs-

  • Football sign
  • Falciform ligament sign
  • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - It is visualized in the pelvis as a result of the free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.

Right upper quadrant sign-

  • Morison's pouch sign (doge cap sign) - Air in the Morison pouch, bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant, presents as either a triangular-shaped, crescentic or semicircular lucency.
  • Cupola sign

The radiograph below shows a supine abdominal X-ray of a neonate with a large pneumoperitoneum. An oval lucency divided by the falciform ligament resulting in the so-called football sign is seen on supine film.

Given below is the supine abdominal radiograph of a patient showing pneumoperitoneum and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.

Gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It is seen as lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies. This is called the cupola sign. 

Supine abdomial X-ray given below shows cupola sign.

questions.text: Which of the following air cells is marked by the asterisk in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked area represents the floor of the orbit and Haller cells are present in that area.

Haller cells are an anterior ethmoidal group of hair cells that are present in relation to the floor of the orbit and roof of the maxillary sinus. Enlargement of these hair cells may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells that are present in the agger nasi ridge.
    • Ethmoid bulla that forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells present in the floor of the orbit. 
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. The onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

The image below shows Onodi hair cells.

questions.text:
An MRI scan of a 40-year-old male who presented with hearing difficulty, frequent episodes of tinnitus, and imbalance is given below. Which of the following statements are correct considering the likely diagnosis?
  1. The patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss.
  2. Roll-over phenomenon is seen.
  3. External beam radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.
  4. Most commonly arises from the cochlear division of the VIIIth nerve.
  5. Recruitment phenomenon is present.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and MRI scan are suggestive of acoustic neuroma. Here, the patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss, and the roll-over phenomenon is seen making statements 1 and 2 correct.

Acoustic neuroma also known as vestibular schwannoma or eighth nerve tumor more commonly arises from the vestibular and rarely from the cochlear division of the eighth nerve. It is a cerebellopontine angle tumour mostly seen in the age group of 40–60 years.

Clinically, patients with acoustic neuroma are present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Poor speech discrimination on speech audiometry is the characteristic feature of acoustic neuroma. Vestibular symptoms like imbalance or unsteadiness are seen.

Hitzelberger’s sign which is the hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall when the tumor affects the sensory fibers of the facial nerve is seen.

Roll-over phenomenon which is the reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is commonly observed. Recruitment phenomenon is absent.

MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. Ice-cream cone appearance of the tumor is seen.

Surgical removal of the tumor is the treatment of choice. The approach depends on the size of the tumor. 

External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures. Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery.

questions.text: What is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image of the gluteal region?

choices.text: Causes lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
Causes abduction of the thigh in flexion
Sciatic nerve lies closely related to the muscle

questions.solution:
The structure marked is the piriformis muscle.

The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It passes outside the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

It inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibers or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position.

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: A child presents with a history of severe sunburns just after a few minutes in the sun.  Severe freckling is noted in the sun-exposed areas as shown below. The autosomal recessive condition responsible for this is due to:
questions.solution:
The image and history point to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by Defective Nucleotide Excision repair.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. This leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

In XP the skin is normal at birth and has a three-stage progression:

  • Diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle-like areas over the sun-exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.
  • The second stage is characterized by poikiloderma. This results in skin atrophy, telangiectasias with mottled hyperpigmentation, and hyperpigmentation.
  • In the third stage appearance of cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma. 

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

Other options:

Option A: Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ) is seen in Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).

Option C: Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER) leads to MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP).

Option D: Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR) causes Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a potential complication of rapid sequence intubation (RSI)?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a potential complication of rapid sequence intubation (RSI), but hypotension is a potential complication.

The following are the potential complications of RSI:

  • Hypoxia - as a result of oxygen desaturation during a brief period of apnea prior to intubation
  • Hypotension - mainly observed in hemodynamically unstable patients
  • Regurgitation - rare, but occurs if preventive manoeuvres such as application of cricoid pressure fail
  • Aspiration - incidence is rare but occurs in 0.15% of cases. This leads to potential complications such as tracheal irritation, infection, airway obstruction, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Difficult or failed airway

RSI is a technique of anesthesia induction in patients who are at an increased risk of gastric regurgitation and pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents. Common cases include pregnancy, full stomach, intestinal obstruction, poorly controlled gastroesophageal reflux disease, morbid obesity, and diabetic gastroparesis. The goal is to intubate rapidly to minimize the time between the loss of consciousness and securing of the airway with a cuffed endotracheal tube.

questions.text: To assess the vitamin B1 nutritional status in a patient, measurement of which of the following can be used?
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status.

Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and requires Mg2+ and thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1) as cofactors. In thiamine deficiency, the RBC transketolase activity is reduced. When thiamine diphosphate is added in-vitro to erythrocyte lysate, activation of apo-transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

Other enzymes requiring thiamine as a cofactor are:
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase
Options A and B: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase are involved in the oxidative phase of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway. Both enzymes require NADP+ and contribute to the formation of NADPH and ribose.
 
Option D: The vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese female patient who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 2 years ago has come for a change of medication. She has a history of osteoporosis and does not want to take any injectable medications.  Which of the following drugs can be prescribed for her diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
In an obese patient with a history of osteoporosis who does not wish to take injectable medications, semaglutide is the most appropriate drug which can be given.

GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide) analogs increase insulin secretion, reduce glucagon release, delay gastric emptying, and normalize fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. GLP-1 analogs have been found to promote weight loss. Semaglutide is a member of this class that is available as an oral formulation, while all the other GLP-1 agonists are injectable drugs. 

GLP-1 analogs can cause hypoglycemia when in combination with insulin or sulfonylureas. They increase the risk of pancreatitis and medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A: Canagliflozin is an inhibitor of sodium-glucose transporter 2 which is located in the proximal tubule of the nephron. It reduces the rate of glucose reabsorption and reduces the renal threshold for glucose excretion. It reduces mortality in cardiovascular patients with type II diabetes mellitus. This drug is not preferred in this patient as it can decrease bone mineral density leading to an increased risk of fractures.

Option B: Liraglutide is also a GLP-1 receptor agonist and is given only in the subcutaneous injectable form. It has recently also been approved for the treatment of obesity.

Option D: Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones group. It activates PPARγ receptors primarily in the adipose tissue which increases insulin sensitivity and adipose differentiation. They enhance the insulin action in the liver, adipose tissue, and skeletal muscle and improve glycemic control in diabetics. This drug is not preferred in this patient as it can lead to further weight gain and adiposity, leading to increased risk of fractures. Hence, it is best avoided in patients with osteoporosis. The other important adverse effects include edema (fluid retention), macular edema, and increased risk of heart failure.

questions.text: An 8-week-old child presents with watering and discharge of the eye. On performing the fluorescein dye disappearance test, the dye that is placed into the inferior cul-de-sac does not drain into the nose within 5 minutes. Which of the following is the next step of management that can be done in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The next step that can be done in this child is massaging over the lacrimal sac, also known as Criggler's massage.

The initial treatment involves performing nasolacrimal massage, typically 2-3 times daily, along with cleansing the eyelids using warm water and applying topical antibiotics. To initiate nasolacrimal massage, the index finger is placed over the common canaliculus to prevent reflux, and then gently rolled over the lacrimal sac in a downward direction.

Nasolacrimal duct obstruction is the most common disease of the lacrimal system. It usually presents in the first few weeks or months of life as excessive tearing and ocular discharge. It mostly occurs due to incomplete canalization of the duct.

Typically, diagnosis is established through a combination of patient history and physical examination. In cases where symptoms are intermittent, the presence of an obstruction can be confirmed using the fluorescein dye disappearance test. During this test, one drop of fluorescein-stained saline is placed in the inferior cul-de-sac of patient's eye, and any excess tears are carefully removed. Under normal conditions, the dye should fully drain into the nose within 5 minutes, indicating an unobstructed passage. However, in the presence of an obstruction, the dye fails to completely clear, suggesting a blockage.

If a case does not resolve after massaging by the age of 6 to 10 months, lacrimal duct probing is done and the probe is pushed through the obstruction. The patency of the duct is then checked using fluorescein-stained saline. In cases where symptoms are mild to moderate, the probing procedure may be postponed until the child reaches the age of 12 to 18 months, or possibly even 24 months.

If probing fails, other treatment options include intubation with silastic tubing with or without balloon dilatation of the nasolacrimal duct and dacryocystorhinostomy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman doing moderate work,  asks for your advice regarding the additional energy requirement while breastfeeding her newborn child. What is the additional calorie requirement in her case?
questions.solution:
A woman doing moderate work with a newborn in the initial lactation period (0-6 months) requires an additional 600 kcal/day.

A woman doing moderate work requires 2130 kcal of energy per day. During pregnancy, an additional 600 Kcal/day of energy is required.

During the lactation period, of 6-12 months, an additional 520 kcal/day is needed.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is/are used in tubal patency testing?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. All the above instruments are used in tubal patency testing. 

Image 1 shows Rubins Insufflation Cannula.

It requires a ‘Y’ rubber tube. One end is attached to a bulb and the other end to a manometer.

Uses: To know the patency of the tube (Rubin’s test) in infertility investigation or following tuboplasty.

 

Image 2 shows Cervical occlusion clamp.

  • The blades are guarded with rubber tubes to avoid trauma to tissues.
  • Cervix is occluded with the instrument and methylene blue dye is injected into the uterine cavity through the fundus using a syringe and a needle.

Uses: Evaluation of tubal patency during laparotomy (following tuboplasty).

 

Image 3 shows Hysterosalpingographic cannula.

It is required to push the iodine containing radio-opaque dye (urograffin) into the uterus during hysterosalpingography.

Uses:

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate tubal patency.
  • Hydrotubation.

questions.text: Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by ________
questions.solution:
Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by the rubella virus.

The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataracts, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions is referred to as expanded rubella syndrome. The thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term blueberry muffin syndrome. 

While the blueberry muffin syndrome is characteristically caused by rubella, the blueberry muffin-like hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions may also be seen in the case of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

The following image shows blueberry syndrome:

Other options: Maternal varicella occurring close to delivery may cause congenital varicella syndrome in babies in the first 2 weeks of life. This presents as a serious disseminated disease with a risk of encephalitis and pneumonia.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: All of the following result in the change of gene frequencies in a population except:
questions.solution:
In a Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium state, there is no change in gene frequencies. 

The Hardy-Weinberg law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tend to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of forces that change the gene frequencies. A population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium would not have any change in the gene frequencies.

But, this is a theoretical concept, and in practice, the human population is never in an equilibrium state because of the action of the following forces that result in the change of gene frequencies from generation to generation:

  • Mutation
  • Natural Selection
  • Population movements
  • Breeding structure resulting in nonrandom mating
  • Public health measures

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: Which organism shows the below-depicted phenomenon when incubated with staphylococcus aureus on blood agar?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism which is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when incubated on blood agar along with Staphylococcus aureus.

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Thus factor V is present in high concentrations near the streak. The Hemophilus colonies become progressively smaller further away from the streak because the factor V concentration becomes less. 

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic, obese man presented to the OPD. His lipid profile showed hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated LDL and VLDL. Which of the following vitamins can be used for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and elevated LDL levels point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia or Type II hyperlipoproteinemia. Nicotinic acid (niacin or Vitamin B3) is used in treatment as a lipid-lowering drug. It lowers lipoprotein levels significantly.

Lipolysis in adipose tissues is the major producer of free fatty acids (FFA). The liver converts FFAs to triacylglycerol (TAG) which is used to synthesize very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is derived from VLDL in the plasma. By inhibiting this lipolysis in adipose tissues, niacin causes a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides. So it is particularly useful in the treatment of type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia, in which both VLDL and LDL are elevated. Niacin also increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels and is prescribed at a dose of 1.5 grams per day.

The main adverse effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing and pruritus which can be controlled by pretreatment with aspirin. Niacin also causes hepatotoxicity, GI toxicity, and hyperuricemia.

2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: The autopsy of a 1-year-old child who died of congestive cardiac failure revealed multiple tumours of the heart located in the ventricles. The histopathologic findings is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells which are characteristic of cardiac rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, cardiac rhabdomyomas are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Histologic processing of the sample usually removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands. These strands stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This gives an appearance that resembles a spider and is hence referred to as spider cells.

Rhabdomyomas are mostly seen in the first year of life. They are discovered when there is an obstruction to a valvular orifice or cardiac chamber. Approximately half the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations. The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are usually multiple and appear in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas and not true neoplasms.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the adult heart. Unlike rhabdomyomas, they are usually single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Papillary fibroelastomas are mainly present in the valves. It appears as a cluster of hairlike projections up to 1 cm in length.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man visits a psychiatrist. He says that he has a feeling that his surroundings are dreamlike, lifeless, unreal, and fictitious. He explains that he feels detached from his surroundings. His reality testing remains intact, and he does not abuse any drugs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A sense of dreamlike, lifeless, unreal, and fictitious surroundings in a person who does not abuse drugs, along with intact reality testing, is suggestive of a diagnosis of derealisation disorder.

Derealisation is a condition characterised by a sense of unreality or feeling detached from one's surroundings. Individuals experiencing derealisation may describe a perception of the external world as lacking clarity and emotional depth, similar to being in a dream-like state or feeling emotionally numb.

Derealisation is frequently observed in patients with seizures and migraines. Additionally, it can occur as a result of using psychedelic drugs, particularly marijuana, lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and mescaline. Less commonly, derealisation can also occur as a side effect of certain medications, including anticholinergic agents.

Since depersonalisation and derealisation disorders have similar presentations, DSM-V lists the following criteria to diagnose them:

  • The presence of persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalisation, derealisation, or both.
  • Intact reality testing during the episodes.
  • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition(e.g., seizures). 
  • The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, major depressive disorder, acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)

questions.text: A child who presents with hypotonia and seizures is diagnosed with Zellweger syndrome. All of the following findings are seen in this patient except?

choices.text: Mutation in PEX family of genes

questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is associated with a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome or cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective biogenesis of peroxisomes. Mutations in the PEX (Option D) family of genes are implicated leading to a defective transport of proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. This affects the metabolic pathways which are exclusive to the peroxisome such as 

  • β oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) is affected leading to the accumulation of VLCFA. (Option B)
  • α oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids (such as phytanic acid) leading to accumulation of phytanic acid.
  • Synthesis of bile acids is affected (Option C) 
  • Synthesis of plasmalogens is affected causing a marked reduction in plasmalogen levels. (Option A) 

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nuchal skin folds. Profound developmental delay, hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis. There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Other diseases of peroxisome are:

Refsum's disease results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition.

In X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, the defect is an inability to transport VLCFA into the peroxisome, but other peroxisomal functions, such as α-oxidation, are normal. Elevated levels of VLCFA are seen in all tissues with normal phytanic acid levels.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with acne conglobata. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Acne conglobata is a severe form of nodulocystic acne and isotretinoin is the treatment of choice. 

Acne conglobata typically presents with tender, disfiguring, interconnecting comedones, cysts, inflammatory nodules, and deep burrowing abscesses which may be located on the face, torso, or limbs.

Acne Treatment :

  • Elimination of comedones by normalization of follicular keratinization,
  • Decreasing sebaceous gland activity,
  • Decreasing the population of P. acnes, and decreasing inflammation.

Minimal to moderate

  • Adequately to local therapy alone.
  • Topical agents such as retinoic acid, benzoyl peroxide, or salicylic acid.
  • Topical antibacterial agents such as azelaic acid, topical erythromycin, or clindamycin.

Moderate to severe acne

  • Systemic therapy, such as doxycycline, 100 mg bid.
  • Minocycline is also useful.

Severe nodulocystic acne

  • Synthetic retinoid isotretinoin. 
  • Severe adverse events such as teratogenicity.
  • In addition, patients receiving this medication develop extremely dry skin and cheilitis and must be followed for the development of hypertriglyceridemia.
  • Recently, there have also been concerns that isotretinoin is associated with severe depression in some patients.

questions.text: A patient with hyponatremia caused due to SIADH has which of the following features?

choices.text: Euvolemia, UNa< 40 mmol/L and Uosm< 100 mOsm/kg
Hypovolemia, UNa> 40 mmol/L and Uosm< 100 mOsm/kg
Euvolemia, UNa >40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg
Hypovolemia, UNa <40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg

questions.solution:
A patient with hyponatremia caused due to SIADH has euvolemia with UNa >40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg. 

SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. Excessive ADH acts on renal V2 receptors to increase free water retention, therefore only H2O is reabsorbed and not solutes making the urine concentrated (UNa >40 and Uosm >100) and the serum dilute producing hyponatremia.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient complains of chest pain radiating to the neck and the left arm. He was started on medications that included trimetazidine as one of them. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of this drug?

choices.text: Shift from glucose to free fatty acid metabolism
Shift from free fatty acid to glucose metabolism
Agonist at ATP sensitive potassium channels

questions.solution:
Trimetazidine causes the metabolism to shift from free fatty acids to glucose. This requires less oxygen and is beneficial in ischemia. 

Trimetazidine is an antianginal agent which blocks the thiolase enzyme, the final enzyme in the β-oxidation of fatty acids. This causes a partial shift in the metabolism of the myocardium from free fatty acids to glucose. Glucose oxidation provides lesser ATP but also requires less oxygen. This is beneficial in ischemic states. 

The most important adverse effect of trimetazidine is the increased risk of movement disorders like Parkinson disease. This risk is higher in older patients and those with kidney dysfunction. Hence, it is used only as an add-on drug in the treatment of angina.

Ranolazine is another second-line anti-anginal drug that acts by blocking late sodium current (option B). Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium channels (option D) and causes vasodilation of both arterial and venous vascular beds. This leads to decreased preload and afterload of the heart.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: In a 35-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident with facial injuries, radiological investigations show a complete separation between the facial bones and the cranial bones. What type of Le-Fort's classification is associated with this pattern of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing complete separation of facial and cranial bones is suggestive of Le-Fort III maxillary fracture. It signifies craniofacial disjunction.

Clinical features include malocclusion of teeth, elongation of the midface, mobility in the maxilla, and CSF rhinorrhoea.

Diagnosis is made with x-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan.

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort III fracture.

 

The image below shows the fracture line in Le-Fort I fracture.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort II fracture.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the type of cell death represented by '3' in the given agarose gel electrophoresis pattern?

choices.text: Inflammation is absent in this type of cell death
There is activation of apoptotic proteases-caspases
There is activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.
It represents control used in electrophoresis

questions.solution:
In the given image of agarose gel electrophoresis of DNA, '3' represents necrosis. In necrosis, DNA is cleaved by the activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.

  • Lane 1 represents control.
  • Lane 2 represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. This pattern is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. A DNA ladder is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA between nucleosomes to generate fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs).
  • Lane 3 represents a smear pattern seen in the case of necrosis. In necrosis, DNA is usually not cut in an orderly manner due to the activation of nonspecific lysosomal nucleases.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is given below. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Which of the following correctly describes the manometric evaluation of this disorder?

IRP: integrated relaxation pressure
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. It is characterized by high median IRP and absent peristalsis.

Disorders of esophageal motility can be classified as:

Disorders of esophago-gastric junction (EGJ) outflow: elevated IRP

  • Achalasia cardia: elevated IRP and peristalsis absent
  • EGJ outflow obstruction: elevated IRP and peristalsis present

Disorders of peristalsis: normal IRP

  • Absent contractility
  • Distal esophageal spasm
  • Hypercontractile esophagus

Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach. This is accompanied by relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median IRP. Moreover, there is a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to megaesophagus.

On upper GI scopy, achalasia can show accumulated saliva or food residue in the lower part of the esophagus, but is often reported normal. Upper GI scopy is an important investigation to rule out a mechanical cause of progressive dysphagia, such as a malignancy. Barium contrast studies show a hold-up of the contrast material in the distal esophagus, giving rise to the bird beak appearance.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 24-year-old Rh-negative G2P1 mother was delivered by cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation. The baby is found to be Rh-positive. To access fetomaternal transfusion a Kleihaeur Betke test was done which detected 20 ml of fetal RBCs. What is the dose of anti-D that should be administered to the mother? (Assume fetal hematocrit to be 50 percent)
questions.solution:
10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.Hence for 20 mL of fetal RBCs, 400 µg of anti-D should be administered.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

Principle: Fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Fundus fluorescein angiography was done and it showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance which is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Risk factors:

  • Age: young adults (20–50 years)
  • Sex: male > female
  • Steroid intake 
  • Emotional stress
  • Pregnancy
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Hypertension
  • Sleep apnea syndrome

It is mostly unilateral. Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, relative positive scotoma, micropsia, and metamorphopsia.

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern
  • OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

In the majority of cases, spontaneous resolution is observed. Steroids should be avoided. While the disease tends to be self-limiting, there is a possibility of recurrence. For recurrent and chronic cases, alternative treatment options include laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) injections.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign. A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size seen in central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).

Option A: Cystoid macular edema is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. FFA shows a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance). Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression.

Option C: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

 

Option D: Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs are correctly matched with regards to methylene blue - 3 swab test observation and its interpretation?
  1. The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - Ureterovaginal fistula
  2. The uppermost swab gets stained - Vesicovaginal fistula
  3. Middle swab gets stained -  Vesicovaginal fistula
  4. The lowermost swab gets stained - Urethrovaginal fistula
  5. Swabs don't take up the stain but get soaked with urine - Vesicovaginal fistula
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained -  Vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained - Urethrovaginal fistula

The 3-swab test is done to identify the type of genitourinary fistula. In this test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra, and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The below image shows the 3-swab test.

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section

questions.text:
A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 304B IPC.

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby is being evaluated for recurrent seizure episodes. On examination, a port-wine stain is seen on the face of the child. A CT was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the typical radiological finding in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows tram track calcification seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. The clinical features of facial port-wine stain and seizures also favor the diagnosis.

The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex, seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities

Other options:

Option B: Dawson's fingers: They are periventricular demyelinating plaques perpendicular to the body of lateral ventricles seen in multiple sclerosis. The image below shows Dawson's fingers.

 

Option C: Hot cross bun sign: It is due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Molar tooth sign: It refers to the abnormal anteroposterior orientation of the cerebellar peduncles resembling the roots of a molar tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome (cerebellar vermian dysgenesis). It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following does not indicate chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI)?
questions.solution:
Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) includes ischemic rest pain, ulceration and gangrene, and ABPI <0.4. Chronic limb ischemia usually does not produce paralysis.

Chronic arterial occlusion in the legs presents as intermittent claudication. This is a cramp-like pain that is brought on by walking some distance and relieved by rest, usually within 5 minutes. The pain of intermittent claudication is absent on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis), but is brought on as the patient walks some distance. The distance that the patient is able to walk comfortably — known as claudication distance — decreases as the disease progresses.

At some point, the perfusion to the leg is so severely compromised that there's inadequate oxygen delivery even at rest. This stage is known as rest pain. This kind of pain is worse on lying down or elevation of the foot, because the perfusion is further compromised when the effects of gravity are absent. Severe arterial insufficiency leads to tissue ulceration and gangrene. Patients with CLTI require urgent vascular intervention. Unlike acute limb ischemia, chronic limb ischemia usually does not result in paralysis and loss of sensation.

Quantitative assessment of peripheral arterial disease can be done with ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI). It is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery is the numerator, and the highest brachial systolic pressure is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >1.4:  Calcified vessels (chronic kidney disease, diabetes)
  • >0.9 to < 1.4: Normal
  • <0.9: Hemodynamically significant arterial lesion
  • <0.4 – CLTI

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: A G3P2 woman at 12 weeks of gestation came to the OPD for a routine antenatal checkup. She is asymptomatic. Her urine analysis revealed 2,00,000 gram-negative bacilli per mL. What is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: No treatment is required as she is asymptomatic

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a multiparous woman with no symptoms but a positive urine culture with > 1,00,000 organisms/mL is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Among the given options, administering Amoxicillin 3g is the best next step.

Although treatment can be tailored based on culture results, empiric treatment can also be prescribed using:

  • Single-dose therapy: Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg, or Trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole (320/1600 mg)
  • A 3-day course of amoxicillin(500 mg TDS), Nitrofurantoin (100mg BD), or Trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole (160/800 BD)

Treatment failures are managed with Nitrofurantoin 100mg 4 times a day for 21 days.

Asymptomatic bacteriuria:

This refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women.

Diagnostic criteria: Positive bacterial count of the same species over 1,00,000/mL in midstream clean catch specimen of urine without symptoms of urinary infection.

  • Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The most common causative agent is E.coli. Others- Klebsiella, Proteus.
  • Incidence during pregnancy: 2-7% (similar to that in nonpregnant women)
  • Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES)
  • More common in sickle cell anemia/trait, and diabetics
  • If not treated ~25% develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy (such as pyelonephritis)
  • Associated with hypertension, anemia, premature labor, intrauterine growth retardation, and urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases.
  • There is a high risk of developing chronic renal lesions in later life.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes for a follow-up after a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) one week back. He complains of not being able to name anything. On examination, he understands and talks normally, but he is unable to repeat the words told to him. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure affected in this patient is the arcuate fasciculus.

The above clinical features are suggestive of conduction aphasia as his comprehension of spoken language and speech fluency is intact with repetition being impaired. Naming is impaired here. The site of lesion usually affected in conduction aphasia is the arcuate fasciculus.

Arcuate fasciculus is short association fibres that connect the temporal cortex and inferior parietal cortex to the frontal lobe. One of its important connections is that between the Broca's area and Wernicke's area.

Association fibres: They connect various cortical areas within the same hemisphere. They are classified as:

  1. Short association fibres: they connect adjacent gyri. Example: Arcuate fasciculus
  2. Long association fibres: they connect gyri from one lobe to another lobe. Example:
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Fornix 

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is present in the inferior frontal lobe of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, comprehension of language is intact, speech fluency, repetition and naming are impaired.

Option C- Wernicke's area (Brodmann's area 22) corresponds to the supramarginal gyrus within the inferior parietal lobule of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. Lesion to this area results in Wernicke's aphasia or sensory aphasia. In Wernicke's aphasia, comprehension of language, repetition and naming are impaired. Speech fluency is increased associated with new words (neologism) resulting in jargon aphasia.

Option D- Middle longitudinal fasciculus is an association fibre in the superior temporal gyrus connecting angular gyrus (area 39) with the superior temporal gyrus (area 22). It plays a role in linguistic processing with information dealing with the spatial organization, memory, and motivational valence.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agent can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Gadolinium can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a systemic condition that primarily affects the skin of patients with renal impairment. Increased numbers of fibrocytes result in skin thickening and plaque formation which evolves to cause flexion contractures, paraesthesia, and pruritus. As a result, gadolinium-containing contrast is contraindicated in patients with GFR under 30 ml/min

Recent research has also demonstrated radiologically and pathologically detected gadolinium deposition in brain tissue including the dentate nuclei, pons, globus pallidus, and thalamus in patients who have undergone multiple MRI scans using gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs). The clinical significance of this deposition is as yet unknown. Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Other options

Ditrazoate, Ioxaglate, and Iohexol are iodinated contrast agents. Ditrazoate is a high-osmolality contrast agent, Ioxaglate is an iso-osmolality contrast agent and Iohexol is a low-osmolality contrast agent.

They increase the risk of Contrast-induced nephropathy(CIN). Acute Kidney Injury Network (AKIN) criteria for AKI be applied for the diagnosis of CIN. AKI is diagnosed if any one of the following criteria is met:

  • Absolute serum creatinine increase >0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours
  • >50% increase in serum creatinine in 7 days
  • Urine output decreased to <0.5 mL/kg/h for at least 6 hours.

Hence alternative imaging methods, without iodinated contrast media, should be chosen in patients with considerably impaired renal function (CKD 4 or 5). In patients with moderate renal impairment (CKD 3) volume expansion with 0.9% saline at 100 mL/h beginning 6 to 2 hours before CT and continuing for 4 to 12 hours after should be done.

questions.text: In a cirrhotic patient set to undergo a surgery, which of the following muscle relaxants is the agent of choice?
questions.solution:
Atracurium is the agent of choice in cirrhotic and liver failure patients.

Atracurium undergoes spontaneous non-enzymatic degradation at physiological pH and temperature, known as Hofmann elimination. As it is eliminated in an organ-independent manner, severe liver failure does not affect the clearance of atracurium. 

Rocuronium and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion. Pancuronium excretion is primarily renal. A small percentage of the drug is excreted through bile (hepatic elimination). The metabolism and excretion of these drugs are affected in the case of liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: What is the relation between intra-alveolar pressure and atmospheric pressure when lung volume is equal to the functional residual capacity?
questions.solution:
At functional residual capacity (FRC), the pressure of air in the alveoli equals atmospheric pressure.

When the volume of air present in the lungs is FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse inwards is balanced by the tendency of the chest wall to spring outwards. The pressure inside the airways is equal to the atmospheric pressure. Hence, there is no net movement of air during this stage.

At volumes greater than the FRC, the collapsing force of the lung is greater than the expanding force of the chest wall — the entire system wants to collapse. The airway pressure is greater than the atmospheric pressure. Thus, the air flows out of the lungs, along the pressure gradient.

At volumes lesser than the FRC, the expanding force of the chest wall is greater than the collapsing force of the lung — the entire system wants to expand. The airway pressure is less than the atmospheric pressure. Thus, the air flows into the lungs, along the pressure gradient.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with COVID-19 infection develops shortness of breath and is brought to the hospital. His SpO2 increases from 81% to 83% on administering oxygen via facemask at 10 L/min. The decision to deliver oxygen using the device shown below is made. What is its oxygen delivery rate?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is high-flow nasal cannula. It delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min. This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40 L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • The benefits of HFNC include reduced work of breathing, improved gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreased energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (No. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).
