questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about its relapse, complications, and treatment. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam, help to reduce the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures
Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C. Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

Risk Factors for Recurrence of Febrile Seizures:

Major:

  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hr
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at time of presentation

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. A diagnosis of unruptured ectopic pregnancy was made. Baseline beta HCG was measured and medical management with 50mg/m2 of methotrexate was started (Day 1). The serum beta HCG level measured on Day 2 was more than the baseline beta HCG level. What is the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and 7

questions.solution:
Following the administration of methotrexate mean beta hCG levels may rise during the first 4 days followed by a gradual decline. Hence the next best step, in this case, is to measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and day 7.

When to administer an additional dose (Option B)

If serum β-hCG level declines <15%, give additional dose; repeat serum β-hCG in 48 hours and compare with the previous value; a maximum of 4 doses

  
  • If serum β-hCG level does not decline by 15% from day 4 to day 7
  • Less than 15% decline during weekly surveillance
 

If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. A repeat dose is required if the decline is less than 15% between days 4 and 7 - about 20% women would need a repeat dose.

 Medical management is preferred in the following cases:

  • Low initial serum beta-hCG level (Less than 5,000 IU/L)
  • Small ectopic pregnancy size (Less than 4 cm)
  • Absent fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable

Other options

Option A:

Surgical management with salpingectomy or salpingostomy is done when:

  • Criteria for medical management are not met
  • Persistent fetal cardiac activity
  • Cases where beta hCG levels are not decreasing despite medical therapy.

Option C:

The next best step in the management in this case is to measure beta hCG levels. An alternative regimen with KCL is not recommended in this case.

questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The given image shows persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) and the embryological defect causing this is a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges.

This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Deoxygenated blood goes into the right heart and back into systemic circulation via the aorta. Oxygenated blood goes into the left heart and then back into pulmonary circulation via the pulmonary artery. This parallel circulation gives rise to persistent cyanosis as seen in this patient. 

Since the conotruncal ridges also participate in the formation of the interventricular septum, an accompanying ventricular septal defect (VSD) may also be seen. The persistent truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives mixed blood from both sides. 

 

Other options -

Option A - Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

 

Option B - Anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum gives rise to the Tetralogy of Fallot. It is characterized by 4 cardinal features - pulmonary infundibular stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

 

Option D - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who just came back from a trip to Brazil presents with fever, headache, and rash for the last 3 days. He is diagnosed with Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of the drug which should be used to treat him?

choices.text: Acts on 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Acts on transpeptidase and inhibits cell wall synthesis
Acts on 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis

questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the drug of choice for Rocky Mountain spotted fever. It belongs to the tetracycline group of antimicrobials. It acts on the 30s bacterial ribosome subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Therapeutic uses of tetracyclines include:

  • Rickettsial infections such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, scrub typhus, and Q fever
  • Pneumonia due to Steptococcus pneumonia, H. influenzae and atypical organisms
  • Sexually transmitted infections like Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Prevention and treatment of anthrax
  • Brucella, Bartonella, Borrelia infections
  • Mycobacterium marinum (swimming pool granuloma)

Tetracyclines are incompletely absorbed from the gut, leading to alteration of the gut flora due to the high concentration which is left unabsorbed in the intestines. This can cause an overgrowth of some organisms such as yeasts, Enterococci and Pseudomonas during prolonged tetracycline therapy. Children treated with tetracyclines may develop permanent brown discoloration of the teeth. The teratogenic effect associated with tetracyclines is their deposition in the fetal skeleton during pregnancy and depression of bone growth in infants.

Hepatotoxicity and nephrotoxicity can also occur. Demeclocycline causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and has been used for the treatment of SiADH. Other side effects include idiopathic intracranial hypertension and vestibular toxicity.

The main mechanism of resistance to tetracyclines is by a decreased antibiotic influx or acquisition of an energy-dependent efflux pump for the drug. Other mechanisms include a ribosomal protein that displaces tetracycline from its target and enzymatic inactivation of tetracyclines.

Other options:

Option A: Inhibition of DNA gyrase, topoisomerase IV is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones.

Option B: The antibiotics which act on the 50s subunit of bacterial ribosome include chloramphenicol, macrolides, clindamycin, linezolid, and streptogramins.

Option C: Blocking of the transpeptidase enzyme and inhibition of cell wall synthesis is the mechanism of action of penicillins.

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

It clinically presents as a thunderclap headache with neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness and no focal neurological deficit. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur. Hess and Hunt's scale is the most widely used scale to grade the severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The definitive management of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is done surgically by craniotomy and clipping or by endovascular embolization known as coiling. This prevents rebleeding of the aneurysm.

questions.text: A child who was trying to lift a heavy weight suddenly drops it due to muscle relaxation. Which of the following is true about this reflex?

choices.text: Monosynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Monosynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor

questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of an inverse stretch reflex and it is a disynaptic reflex having the Golgi tendon organ as a receptor.

Up to a physiological limit, the harder a muscle is stretched, the stronger the contraction. However, when the tension becomes too great and can cause damage to the muscle fibers, the contraction suddenly stops and the muscle relaxes. This is known as the inverse stretch reflex. 

The receptor for the inverse stretch reflex is the Golgi tendon organ. It lies in series with the muscle fibers and is stimulated by passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle, but mainly the latter. The Golgi tendon organ is innervated by type Ib sensory fibers. These fibers synapse with an inhibitory interneuron which terminates on the motor neuron innervating the same muscle. The inverse stretch reflex is thus disynaptic. Stimulation of the Golgi tendon organ brings about the relaxation of the muscle.

 

Feature Stretch Reflex  Golgi Tendon Reflex 
Receptor Muscle spindle Golgi tendon organ
Afferent fibers Type Ia, Type II Type Ib
Number of synapses Monosynaptic (1 synapse) Disynaptic (2 synapses)
Response Muscle contraction Muscle relaxation
Function Maintains muscle tone, prevents overstretching Prevents excessive force to protect muscle from damage
Example Knee-jerk reflex Dropping a heavy object due to muscle relaxation

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV-positive male presents with raised violaceous plaques. Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis lined encompassing small vessels and slitlike spaces containing red cells with marked hemorrhage, hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Which organism is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) a γ-herpesvirus that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Four forms of KS based on population demographics and risks:

  • Classic KS - Older men of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, or Eastern European descent. It can be associated with malignancy or altered immunity but is not associated with HIV infection.
  • Endemic African KS -  Typically occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals younger than age 40 and can follow an indolent or aggressive course, with prominent lymph node and visceral involvement, occurs in prepubertal children; the prognosis is poor, with an almost 100% mortality within 3 years.
  • Transplant-associated KS occurs in solid organ transplant recipients in the setting of T-cell immunosuppression. Characteristically involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera; cutaneous lesions may be absent.
  • AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS is an AIDS-defining illness - it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy. AIDS-associated KS often involves lymph nodes and disseminates widely to viscera early in its course.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells.

Other options-

Option B: Epstein Barr virus causes Burkitt’s lymphoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, and Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option C: Bartonella henselae causes bacillary angiomatosis especially in immunocompromised patients and is characterised by proliferating cystic blood filled spaces surrounded by a fibromyxoid matrix containing the bacteria. Circumscribed lesions with lobular capillary proliferation and round, open vessels with cuboidal endothelial cells protruding into the vascular lumen are also seen. Mitotic figures are not seen.

Option D: Human papillomavirus type 16 and 18 causes cervical cancer due to mutation in RAS gene.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student comes to the clinic with a history of four episodes of arthritis involving large joints and was recently admitted for new-onset atrial fibrillation. A holosystolic murmur with early diastolic rumbling is heard at the apex. An early diastolic murmur is also heard at the right second intercostal space near the sternal edge. Which of the following is recommended for long-term prophylaxis of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features and a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Monthly penicillin G injections are recommended for long-term prophylaxis.

The findings of mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation indicate the diagnosis of ARF. The presence of atrial fibrillation indicates severe rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis with either oral phenoxymethylpenicillin (250 mg twice daily) or preferably, benzathine benzylpenicillin (1.2 million U IM monthly) is considered the best method to prevent further episodes of ARF, and therefore prevent further valvular damage.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs.

Other options:

Option A: Glucocorticoids are recommended at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg per day (maximum, 80 mg), usually for a few days or up to a maximum of 3 weeks.

Option C: Doxycycline is not a first-line agent for group A Streptococcus, the pathogen that causes ARF.

Option D: Daily aspirin is the treatment of choice for the migratory arthritis of large joints and fever which are common manifestations of ARF.

questions.text: The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host is known as ______
questions.solution:
The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host is known as the generation time.

The time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. In the case of mumps, the maximum communicability appears to reach its height about 48 hours before the onset of swelling of the salivary glands.

Option A: Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Option B: Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the second case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Option D: Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: The given surgical technique has no role in the management of which of the following patients?

choices.text: Patient with carcinoma stomach planned for elective surgery
Patient with severe ongoing hemorrhage and hypothermia

questions.solution:
The surgical technique shown in the image is a vacuum pack for temporary abdominal closure. It is not indicated for a patient with carcinoma stomach planned for elective surgery.

Temporary abdominal closure (TAC) is required in critically ill patients who require physiological optimization prior to any definitive surgery. The ongoing inflammatory response in the abdomen due to any etiology can lead to abdominal compartment syndrome. In this setting, a temporary closure may have to be used as damage control and definitive treatment delayed. The goal of damage control surgery is to achieve hemostasis, control any further contamination, and restore normal physiology as soon as possible. Once these three goals have been achieved, the definitive surgery is planned.

Indications for temporary abdominal closure include:

  • Damage control: patients with severe hemorrhage, hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome
  • Planned re-look laparotomy
  • Severe intra-abdominal sepsis

A vacuum pack for the abdomen is made by using a sheet of plastic (Opsite or Ioban) over the bowel, an intermediate pack of cotton drapes to allow suction, and another sheet of plastic (Opsite or Ioban) draped to the skin to form a watertight and airtight seal. Other techniques of temporary abdominal closure include Bogota bag (shown in the image below) and towel-clip closure.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination and back pain. His PSA levels were found to be elevated and the x-ray pelvis revealed two osteoblastic lesions in the bony pelvis. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?

PSA - Prostate Specific Antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA osteoblastic lesions in the pelvis are suggestive of metastatic prostate cancer. Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs used for this indication are GnRH agonists such as goserelin, buserelin, leuprolide, nafarelin, and triptorelin. The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes an initial increase in LH, leading to increased testosterone production. This causes a tumor flare. This can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist such as flutamide or bicalutamide.

After the initial period, there is a downregulation of GnRH receptors and changes in the downstream pathways, leading to a decrease in gonadotropins and testosterone (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). The androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration in reducing the levels of serum testosterone.

GnRH antagonists such as degarelix can also be used for androgen deprivation therapy. It has the advantage of not having a tumor flare phenomenon. However, because of the long-term safety profile of GnRH agonists, they are the preferred drugs for androgen deprivation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option B: Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option D: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is a weak inhibitor of the androgen receptor and causes gynecomastia as a common side effect. It has been used in women to treat hirsutism.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the hematology findings given below?
questions.solution:

  • Chronic iron toxicity: In severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).

questions.text: Which of the following will result if there is a transection at the level marked as 2 in the given image along with vagotomy?
questions.solution:
A mid-pontine lesion as shown by the level marked 2 in the given image, along with vagotomy, will lead to the stopping of the breath in inspiration, known as apneusis.

The pacemakers of normal breathing, neurons of the pre-Botzinger complex are located in the medulla. Dorsal and ventral groups of respiratory neurons are also present in the medulla. The dorsal group generates the inspiratory impulses independent of any other input into the brainstem. The ventral group is inactive during normal quiet breathing, but provides expiratory signals to abdominal muscles during forceful expiration.

The impulses generated by the dorsal group are initially irregular. They are made regular by the input from the apneustic center located in the lower pons. Apneustic center itself is under inhibitory control of the pneumotaxic center, located in the upper part of the pons.

A transection below the medulla stops all spontaneous breathing because the inspiratory signals from the dorsal group are not able to act.

A transection between the medulla and the pons makes the breathing irregular, because the influence of the apneustic center on the dorsal group of neurons is gone. 

A transection at the mid-pontine level removes the influence of pneumotaxic center on the apneustic center. If the vagi are intact, this results in regular, deep breathing. If the vagi are also cut, it leads to prolonged inspiratory effort, known as apneusis.

A transection above the level of pons has no effect on breathing. If the vagi are also cut, the breathing becomes deeper.

questions.text: A 23-year-old in the postnatal period after her first delivery developed a uterine prolapse of the level given below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Various surgeries were performed for the management of uterovaginal prolapse:

  1. Anterior colporrhaphy: This is done for cystocele or cystourethrocele.
  2. Posterior colporrhaphy/ colpoperineorrhaphy: This is done for posterior defects like rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.
  3. Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline.
  4. Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:
    1. Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
    2. Shirodkar's sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
    3. Khanna's sling surgery - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 
  5. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): An anterior colporrhaphy is combined with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are then sutured in front of the cervix followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy. It is suitable for women <40 years desiring reproductive function, but fertility may be reduced.
  6. Ward-Mayo surgery: This is a combination of vaginal hysterectomy + pelvic floor repair. It is done in women >40 years, not desiring reproductive function.
  7. Moschowitz surgery: This is performed for enterocele repair where the pouch of Douglas is obliterated.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of episodes of sudden locking of the left knee joint. There is no history of trauma. On examination, a mass is palpable which slips away. X-ray of the knee joint reveals that this mass is radiopaque. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of loose bodies in the knee joint of an adult

Loose bodies are fragments of bone, cartilage, or fibrous tissue that are present within the joint cavity. The common causes of loose bodies in the knee joint are:

  • Osteochondritis dissecans (adolescents)
  • Osteoarthritis (adults)
  • Charcot's disease
  • Synovial osteochondromatosis (cartilage metaplasia in the synovium, sometimes producing hundreds of loose bodies)

The commonest complaint is attacks of sudden locking without injury. There is a sensation of something popping in and out of the joint. On examination, a mass may be palpable which tends to slip away(Joint mouse). Most of the loose bodies are radiopaque on X-ray. Management includes arthroscopic removal of the loose body.

Although loose bodies may be associated with osteochondritis dissecans, considering the age of the patient, osteoarthritis is the better answer. Loose bodies in adolescents are typically due to osteochondritis dissecans while loose bodies in an adult are more commonly due to osteoarthritis.

questions.text: In which one of the following tissues is glucose transport into the cell insulin dependent?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter GLUT-4 in adipose tissue (and muscle) is dependent on insulin. Insulin results in the transport of GLUT-4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane. The brain, liver, and red blood cells contain GLUTs that are independent of insulin because they are always located on the cell membrane.

questions.text: An infant with an umbilical hernia is brought by his parents to the OPD. He is noted to have coarse facial features, macroglossia, and hepatomegaly on examination. He is diagnosed to have a disease affecting the degradation of mucopolysaccharides in lysosomes. Which of the following cannot differentiate Type I from the Type II subset of this disease?
questions.solution:
The presence of coarse facial features, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and visceromegaly with defective degradation in lysosomes is suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses. Intellectual disability can be seen in both Type I and Type II mucopolysaccharidoses and cannot help differentiate the two.

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They are attached to proteins to form proteoglycans, which make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue. Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

  • Type I MPS or Hurler's syndrome is caused due to deficiency of the α-L-iduronidase enzyme.
  • Type II MPS or Hunter's syndrome is caused due to deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase enzyme. 

Both enzyme deficiencies lead to the accumulation of dermatan and heparan sulfate. Common features of both Type I and II MPS include the presence of coarse facial features, intellectual disability, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, and dysostosis multiplex.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male was brought to the ER following a head injury. His GCS is 15/15 and there is no focal neurological deficit. The following finding is noted on examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in a patient with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) with a sign of base of skull fracture (Battle sign as shown in the image) is CT scan of the head.

Mild TBI is defined as a post-resuscitation GCS score between 13 and 15. These patients might have a history of a transient loss of neurological function in the form of disorientation, amnesia, or transient loss of consciousness. The indications for performing a CT scan in a patient with mild TBI are:

  • GCS score <15 at 2 hours after injury
  • Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
  • Signs of base of skull fracture: hemotympanum, raccoon eyes (as shown in the image below), CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea, Battle sign
  • >2 episodes of vomiting
  • Age >65 years
  • Anticoagulant use
  • Loss of consciousness >5 minutes or amnesia prior to injury
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury: pedestrian stuck by motor vehicle, occupant ejected from motor vehicle, fall from height more than 3 feet

 

If these indications are absent in a patient with mild TBI, the patient is observed with serial GCS examinations until the GCS is 15 and the patient has no memory deficit. Following this, the patient is discharged.

All cases of moderate (GCS 9-12) and severe (GCS 3-8) traumatic brain injury mandatorily require a CT scan for further evaluation.

questions.text: For how long should you maintain records of medical termination of pregnancy?

choices.text: For at least 7 years, from the end of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 10 years, from the beginning of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 3 years, from the beginning of the calendar year of MTP
For at least 5 years, from the end of the calendar year of MTP

questions.solution:
A register for recording the details of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must be kept for at least 5 years, from the end of the calendar year it relates to. The patient's name must not be entered; only the reference number is used.

Unlawful disclosure of a patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment with or without fine. Only the patient's consent is required for MTP; her male partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known hypertensive presented with pain and swelling in his great toe. The aspirated synovial contents visualized under polarized light microscopy showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. What is the antihypertensive that is preferred in such patients?
questions.solution:
Losartan is the preferred antihypertensive in patients having gout, because of its uricosuric action.

Losartan inhibits active sites for reabsorption and secretion in the proximal renal tubule, hence the net reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubule is decreased. Similarly, calcium channel blockers like amlodipine and diltiazem are found to lower the risk of gout.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of gout flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory hypoxic conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light. WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors(eg. allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (e.g. probenecid) can be used.

Other options-

Options A and D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors like captopril are associated with an increased risk of incident gout among patients with hypertension. β blockers such as propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, and alprenolol, also have been shown to increase serum uric acid levels. 

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text: The histology slide of cartilage is given below.  Which of the following statements is incorrect about this type of cartilage?

choices.text: It predominantly consists of type II collagen

questions.solution:
The given image shows fibrocartilage. The incorrect statement about this cartilage is that it mainly contains type 2 collagen. A fibrocartilage contains both type 1 and 2 collagen but is predominantly made of type I collagen.

Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components makes this tissue extremely tough and resilient. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by the presence of chondrocytes and the matrix containing abundant collagen fibres. 

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • Menisci of the knee
  • Glenoid and acetabular labra
  • The lining of the bony grooves for tendons
  • Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

The image below shows - hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage, and elastic cartilage respectively.

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective cohort study. This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome, the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
 
A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future. The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers were classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
 
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
 
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A patient presents with high colored urine. A urine dipstick test done was positive. On further evaluation by centrifugation at 2000rpm for 5 min, the sample was still high colored but became colorless after about 3 hours.  Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myoglobinuria is most likely in this patient.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme which is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or due to porphyrias.

Myoglobinuria is the presence of an excess amount of myoglobin in the urine. It is mostly caused by muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury. 

Causes of myoglobinuria:

  • Physical causes are trauma, crush injury, heatstroke, hypothermia, malignant hyperthermia, extensive burns, seizures, strenuous exercise, and prolonged immobility.
  • Non-physical causes include hypoxic injury, metabolic disturbances, genetic disorders, infections, drugs, and toxins.

The primary goal of treatment in the case of myoglobinuria is to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI), and for that, the initial therapy is mainly focused on rehydration to facilitate the renal clearance of myoglobin.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

  • The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palanosetron.
     
  • The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palanosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient was found to have a BP of 146/94 mmHg. His laboratory findings are given below. Which of the following will be the most appropriate anti-hypertensive for this patient?

Fasting blood sugar: 200 mg/dL

Post-prandial blood sugar: 320 mg/dL

HbA1C: 9%
questions.solution:
The most appropriate anti-hypertensive drug for this patient would be telmisartan. Telmisartan has PPARγ agonistic activity, leading to improved insulin sensitivity in patients with diabetes mellitus.

By acting as an agonist on PPARγ receptor, telmisartan regulates the downstream glucose and lipid metabolism. It increases basal and insulin-stimulated uptake of glucose into the adipocytes via GLUT-4. It also decreases the amount of reactive oxygen species and increases serum adiponectin. By these mechanisms, it improves oxidative stress and insulin resistance in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Furthermore, it has been shown to reduce cardiac fibrosis and hypertrophy.

ACE inhibitors such as Lisinopril (option B) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are able to stop the progression of diabetic nephropathy in patients with diabetes mellitus. They are the first-line anti-hypertensive drugs in diabetic patients. However, because of its additional beneficial effects as described above, telmisartan is preferred.

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic (option A) and amlodipine, a DHP type of calcium channel blocker (option D) offer no added advantage to the treatment of hypertensive patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman hailing from China has been diagnosed with Keshan's disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Glutathione peroxidase has the involved element
Deficient element is a component of  the 22nd amino acid

questions.solution:
Keshan's disease occurs due to selenium deficiency which is a component of the 21st amino acid - Selenocysteine. 

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where the dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D) is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis (Option C).

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of Selenocysteine. Selenocysteine is the 21st amino acid coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. It is formed by co-translational modification. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase (Option A)
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing parotidectomy. Which of the following measures reduces the risk of the development of Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating occurs as a result of aberrant innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve following parotid surgery. This can be prevented intraoperatively by placing a temporalis fascia flap between the skin and the parotid bed.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. The diagnosis can be confirmed with Minor's starch-iodine test. This test involves applying iodine and dry starch over the suspected area, and giving a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue.

Frey's syndrome occurs as a consequence of parotidectomy in most patients but is usually not significant. It can be prevented by the following methods:

  • Raising a thick flap (including the subcutaneous tissue) over the parotid
  • Interposition of tissues such as sternocleidomastoid flap, temporalis fascia or autologous fat between the skin and the surgical bed
  • Extracapsular dissection of parotid gland for benign pathologies

Treatment of established Frey's syndrome involves the use of anti-perpirants, botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin, and neurectomy of the Jacobson's nerve, which forms the tympanic plexus and gives the pre-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion, in the form of lesser petrosal nerve.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for one day. On further inquiry, you find out there is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used in the removal of them. 0.05 mg per 100 grams of food material is the upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. The given trophozoite stage is found in the stool sample. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the trophozoite stage of Balantidium coli. It is the only ciliated pathogenic protozoa infecting humans and is present in the large intestine as a commensal. It is the largest protozoan parasite of humans.

Trophozoite:

  • Large ovoid cell enclosed within a delicate pellicle showing longitudinal striations.
  • Has a narrow anterior end and a broad posterior end.
  • The cell has 2 nuclei—a large kidney-shaped macronucleus and a small micronucleus lying in its concavity.
  • 1 or 2 contractile vacuoles and several food vacuoles are present in the cytoplasm
  • There is a groove (peristome) at the anterior end that leads to the mouth (cytostome), and a short funnelshaped gullet (cytopharynx).
  • A small anal pore (cytopyge) is present posteriorly.
  • The cilia around the mouth are larger (adoral cilia)
  • Lives in the large intestine and feeds on cell debris, bacteria, starch grains, and other particles.
  • The trophozoite is actively motile due to the presence of short delicate cilia over the entire surface of the body. The invasive stage of the parasite is found in dysenteric stool.

Cyst:

  • It is spherical and measures 40–60 μm in diameter
  • A thick and transparent double-layered wall surrounds it
  • The cytoplasm is granular and has the macronucleus, micronucleus, and vacuoles present.
  • The cyst is the infective stage of B. coli and is found in chronic cases and carriers.

Balantidiasis is a zoonosis that is mostly asymptomatic. Pigs are the definitive hosts and man is an accidental host. Symptomatic disease presents with diarrhea or dysentery. The presence of intestinal ulcers and submucosal abscesses resembles amoebiasis.

The following image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidum coli.

questions.text: Thyroxine stimulating hormone is elevated in hypothyroidism.  A new test is employed and results are being interpreted from a hilly city and a coastal city to detect elevated TSH levels due to hypothyroidism. Which of the following is true regarding the test?

choices.text: If a person from hilly city tests positive, he is more likely to actually to have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests positive from coastal city
If a person from hilly city tests negative , he is less likely to have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests negative  from coastal city
A person having  hypothyroidism is likely to test positive in hilly city than coastal city
A person not having  hypothyroidism is likely to test negative in hilly city than coastal city

questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is more prevalent in hilly areas than in coastal areas. If someone from a hilly city tests positive he is more likely to have the disease than someone who tests positive in a coastal area.

Positive predictive value (PPV) increases with an increase in prevalence. It refers to the chances of having the disease if the test turns out to be positive.

Similarly, if someone tests negative coastal area, he is more likely to not have hypothyroidism, than someone who tests negative in a hilly area.

These results can be interpreted with an analogy of malaria being more prevalent in India than in the UK. If a person tests malaria positive in India, he is more likely to actually have the disease, than being testes positive by chance. Similarly, if a person tests malaria negative in the UK, that is because he might not have the disease. Whilst we might still think of the person having malaria, and being tested negative by chance. Thus, just tested positive or negative doesn't hold a significance, it has to be interpreted in terms of how common the disease is, in that particular area.

The other options of having the disease and testing positive depend on the sensitivity of the test, not on the prevalence of the disease.

Whilst not having the disease and testing negative depends on the specificity of the test, not on the prevalence of the disease.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with a gunshot wound to the abdomen as shown below. On examination, the peritoneum is breached. BP is 114/78 mmHg and HR is 80 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage has bile, gastrointestinal contents or ≥10 cc of blood

CT scan of the abdomen (option B) should be performed in patients with blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma, provided they are hemodynamically stable and have no indication for immediate laparotomy. The patient in question has a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a peritoneal breach, which is an indication for exploratory laparotomy as it carries a high risk of organ injury. FAST (option C) is primarily indicated in patients with blunt abdominal trauma with or without hemodynamic instability. It is not a sensitive investigation to detect hollow visceral injury in patients with penetrating abdominal trauma. There is no role for observation (option D) in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Schroeders' ring?

choices.text: Common cause is injudicious administration of oxytocics
The ring can be felt per abdomen
It is usually formed around the neck of the fetus

questions.solution:
The ring is not felt per abdomen.

Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin results in the formation of a constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring.

It is usually situated at the junction of the upper and lower segment of the uterus around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation. The ring is not felt per abdomen. The uterus never ruptures.

Common causes are:

  • Injudicious use of oxytocics
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • A premature attempt at instrumental delivery

Management

Delivery is usually done by cesarean section. The ring usually passes off by deepening the plane of anesthesia otherwise the ring may have to be cut vertically to deliver the baby.

questions.text: An epidemic of cholera has broken out and public health workers are taking rigorous measures to control the infection. Which of the following methods is preferred to disinfect small household wells in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The double pot method is preferred for disinfecting small wells as an emergency measure. This is because a constant dose of chlorine is desirable at the time of emergencies like a cholera epidemic.

Using bleaching powder is the most effective and cheapest method of disinfecting wells. The double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it. The inner pot has it in the upper portion and the outer pot it is placed 4 centimeters above the bottom. The hole in the outer pot is covered with polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled up to 3 centimeters below the hole with a mixture of bleaching powder and coarse sand. It is then placed in the outer pot. The double pot system is then lowered into a well and immersed at least 1 meter below the water level. It can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 liters of water.

Other options:

Option A: Horrock's apparatus is used to estimate the dose of bleaching powder needed for the disinfection of water. 

Option C: High-test hypochlorite also known as perchloron has 60-70% of available chlorine. It is more stable than bleaching powder and deteriorates less on storage. It is carried out for household purification of water.

Option D: Multi-stage reverse osmosis method is used for household purification of water. It makes water both chemically and microbiologically potable. It has a clarity cartridge and reverse osmosis cartridge.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fatigue, diarrhea, and weight loss. She reports that the stool is bulky, pale, and foul-smelling. On examination, she has pallor and itchy rashes on her elbows, as shown below. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are noted to be positive. Which of the following is not a typical manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy, and hyposplenism (not hypersplenism) is a typical manifestation. 

The image shows grouped erythematous papules and vesicles over the elbow. This is dermatitis herpetiformis, the cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease. It generally presents on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. These lesions are intensely pruritic and occur due to IgA deposits in dermal papillae.

Celiac disease is characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase leading to an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria and impairs nutrient absorption. Gluten is commonly found in wheat, barley, and rye. 

It is characterized by:

  • Gastrointestinal manifestations such as bloating and irregular bowel habits. There is villous atrophy in the proximal intestine causing steatorrhea (bulky, pale, and foul-smelling) as well as fluid hypersecretion from crypt epithelium. 
  • Other manifestations: 
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis - pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of the limbs
    • Deficiency of vitamins B12 and E causing ataxia and peripheral neuropathy
    • Iron-deficiency anemia (Option B)
    • Hyposplenism due to excessive loss of lymphocytes through inflamed intestinal mucosa, leading to spleen’s reticuloendothelial atrophy.
    • Abnormal liver enzymes
    • Increased risk of malignancy such as enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (Option C) and small-bowel adenocarcinoma (Option D).
    • Refractory celiac disease 

Screening for celiac disease is done by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. Diagnosis is confirmed by small-intestinal biopsy, which shows characteristic villus blunting and crypt hyperplasia and inflammation. Given below is a histopathological image of celiac disease:

Treatment of celiac disease involves strict avoidance of gluten.

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. What is the mechanism of action of the organism most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus which acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea. 

Gastroenteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Other options:

Option A: The cholera enterotoxin of Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. It then causes the accumulation of cAMP. A clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera.

Option B: The enterotoxin of Bacillus cereus involves stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system. It may also cause food poisoning independent of the cAMP system. Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is suggestive of B. cereus. Emetic strains of this organism also cause food poisoning within the time period of 2-6 hrs and present with vomiting. Diarrhea is not common with the emetic strains.

Option C: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

questions.text:
A plastic surgeon is planning a split-skin grafting procedure. Arrange the following phases in the correct order during the take of the graft?
  1. Neovascularization
  2. Imbibition
  3. Adherence
  4. Inosculation
questions.solution:
The correct order of phases during the take of a split skin graft at a recipient site is: imbibition → inosculation → neovascularization → adherence.

During the first 48 hours following the placement of the graft on the recipient site, the graft survives by getting nourishment from the plasma exudate from the capillaries of the recipient bed. This is known as imbibition or plasmatic circulation. After 48 hours, the cut-ends of the blood vessels of both the graft and the recipient bed align together to form anastomoses. This phase is called inosculation. Neovascularization refers to the in-growth of the blood vessels from the recipient site into the graft. The organization of the graft begins immediately following the placement of the graft due to the formation of a fibrin layer. The graft becomes adherent to the bed by days 10-14.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. Which of the following is the definitive host of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the thin blood smear showing a maltese cross appearance, is suggestive of Babesia microti infection. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks, whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria and is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common, and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit, which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

The image given below shows the maltese cross appearance seen in infection with Babesia microti.

Other options:

Option A: Protozoan parasite Leishmania is transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly.

Option C: Plasmodium species is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito.

Option D: Rickettsia akari is transmitted by Gamasid mites and causes rickettsial pox.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the primary health center for advice on contraception. She was advised to use the contraceptive provided under the Antara program. The dosage of the drug used in this contraceptive is_____.

I.M: Intramuscular
questions.solution:
The Antara program provides injectable contraceptive MPA (Medroxyprogesterone acetate). The dosage of the drug is 150 mg I.M., every 3 months. 

It acts by inhibiting ovulation, cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration, and endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken anytime after regular menstruation or after 6 weeks of delivery or immediately after abortion. Injectable contraceptives can be given up to 2 weeks prior to the due date to up to 4 weeks after the post-due date.

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for a rapid return to fertility.

Disadvantages are:

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light/heavy bleeding/amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
  • A slight loss in bone mineral density during the first 2 years of use.

This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30oC).

Antara [Injectable contraceptive depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)] and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government of India under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
