questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the great toe. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows crystals of varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms), suggesting uric acid stones. A patient with gout is at a higher risk of developing uric acid stones.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. 

The main risk factors for uric acid stones are low urine pH and higher uric acid excretion. Therefore, the mainstay of prevention of uric acid stone formation is alkalinizing urine and reducing intake of purine-containing foods as uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism. Uric acid excretion can be reduced by the use of a xanthine oxidase inhibitor such as allopurinol or febuxostat. 

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

questions.text: A farmer presents with lesions on his hand as seen in the image below. He gives a history of a thorn prick a few days ago. Histological examination of the lesion showed sclerotic bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing warty lesions on the hand and the presence of sclerotic bodies suggests the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a type of subcutaneous mycoses caused by fungi of the genus Fonsecae and Cladophialophora. It can cause different patterns of lesions like verrucous, nodular, cicatricial, ulcerated, and tumorous.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of yeast-like sclerotic bodies on KOH mount or by culture on Sabouraud agar.

The image given below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the rheumatology clinic with multiple joint pains. Her laboratory reports reveal the presence of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies. Which part of the spine is most commonly affected in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of anti-CCP antibodies point towards the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The most commonly affected part of the spine in RA is cervical.

The atlantoaxial joint - C1 and C2 is the most commonly affected part of the spine in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Other joints commonly affected are - bilateral and symmetrically involved:

  • Metacarpophalangeal joints
  • Wrists
  • Proximal interphalangeal joints
  • Metatarsophalangeal joints

questions.text: There is an outbreak of chickenpox among the children at a daycare center. What is the most common extracutaneous site of involvement of this disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extracutaneous site of involvement by the varicella-zoster virus in children is the central nervous system.

Central nervous system (CNS) involvement is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization. They may develop acute cerebellar ataxia and meningeal inflammation around 21 days after the onset of the rash. The CSF findings include the presence of lymphocytes and elevated levels of protein. Other CNS manifestations include

  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Encephalitis
  • Transverse myelitis
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome

The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus while the most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

Other options:

Option A: Hepatic involvement is common in chickenpox and is usually asymptomatic. It is characterized by elevated levels of liver enzymes, particularly aspartate and alanine aminotransferase. Reye’s syndrome may occur in children concomitantly treated with aspirin and hence is not used.

Option C: Chickenpox may involve the joints and cause arthritis as a complication.

Option D: Lung involvement is more common in adults than children and is more severe in pregnant women. The most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen in an injury to Baum’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Inferior quadrantanopia (pie in the floor) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the parietal lobe. They are also known as Baum’s loop.

Pie in the Sky defects:

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of inferior fibres of Optic radiations – Meyer’s loop
  • Seen in Temporal lobe lesions

Pie in the Floor defects:

  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of superior fibres of the Optic radiations – Baum’s loop
  • Seen in Parietal lobe lesions

Notable points :

  • Lesion in central chiasma – Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Lesion in anterior chiasma – Junctional scotoma
  • Lesion in optic tract – Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • Radiational lesion and cortical blindness has normal pupillary reaction

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
A young adult male met with a road traffic accident and sustained severe injuries to his head and face. On the third day at the hospital, he started experiencing nasal discharge. Which of the following features suggests that the discharge is cerebrospinal fluid?
  1. Drops of fluid gush down on bending forward.
  2. The secretion is thin and clear.
  3. The secretion can be sniffed back
  4. When collected on a piece of filter paper, shows a double target sign.
  5. β2 transferrin is not present in the secretion.
questions.solution:
The features that are suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid are:

  • Drops of fluid gush down on bending forward.
  • The secretion is thin and clear.
  • When collected on a piece of filter paper, shows a double target sign.

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries.

The route by which CSF from the anterior cranial fossa reaches the nose includes the cribriform plate, the roof of ethmoid air cells, or the frontal sinus. In contrast, CSF from the middle cranial fossa follows injuries to the sphenoid sinus. Fractures of the temporal bone can lead to CSF entering the middle ear and escaping through the eustachian tube, resulting in CSF otorhinorrhea.

When CSF rhinorrhea occurs after head trauma, it often contains a mixture of blood, leading to a characteristic appearance known as the double target sign when collected on a piece of filter paper. This sign presents as a central red spot (indicating blood) surrounded by a lighter peripheral halo. Nasal endoscopy can be useful in some cases to locate the site of CSF leakage.

In early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, conservative measures can be employed as initial management. These measures include bed rest, elevating the head of the bed, using stool softeners, and avoiding activities that increase nasal pressure, such as nose blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics may be administered to prevent meningitis. Acetazolamide, a medication that reduces CSF production, can also be employed.

Surgical repair of CSF rhinorrhea can be performed using various approaches, including the neurosurgical intracranial approach, extradural approaches, or the transnasal endoscopic approach. The choice of surgical technique depends on factors such as the location and nature of the CSF leak, as well as the surgeon's expertise.

Features to differentiate between nasal discharge and CSF:

Feature CSF fluid Nasal secretion
History Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation
Flow of discharge A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down when bending forward or training and cannot be sniffed back Continuous. No effect on bending forward or straining. Can be sniffed back
Character of discharge Thin, watery, and clear Slimy (mucous) or clear (tears)
Sugar content More than 30 mg/dl Less than 10 mg/dl
Presence of beta-2 transferrin Always present. It is specific to CSF  Always absent

The image below shows the double target sign.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from her hands, these are precipitated during early morning hours and exams, and the frequency of such jerks increases whenever she is sleep-deprived. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. What can be the most likely EEG finding in this case?

choices.text: 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep

questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), which is characterized by isolated jerks, usually involving both arms; the jerks can be as subtle as finger twitches, but in this case, they manifest as dropping objects. 4-5 Hz epileptic spikes can be seen on the EEG in this condition.

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

  • The hallmark seizures in JME are myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning.
  • Consciousness is preserved.
  • The myoclonus in JME is epileptic, as opposed to physiologic or essential.
  • Patients may have reflex seizures triggered by various types of stimuli, such as writing, reading, praxis, or higher mental activities, and aggravated by sleep deprivation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.

Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.

Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows the histopathological image of FSGS.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of thick, yellow urethral discharge and dysuria. The symptoms developed a few days after the patient had unprotected intercourse with a sex worker. He is diagnosed with gonorrhea. The patient's urethral discharge is inoculated in a selective culture medium. Which of the following drugs is not present in this medium?
questions.solution:
The selective medium used for inoculation in cases of gonorrhea is the Modified Thayer Martin medium. It is a selective medium made up of four antibiotics: vancomycin, nystatin, colistin and trimethoprim. (Sulfamethoxazole is not present)

Selective media contain an inhibiting substance that is added to a solid medium. This inhibits the growth of commensals and favors the growth of the required bacterium.

Thayer-Martin medium is a selective media used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. The antimicrobials present in it suppress the growth of other commensal organisms and selectively favor the growth of Neisseria. The Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar. The modified Thayer-Martin medium has an additional antibiotic trimethoprim to inhibit proteus. 

  • Vancomycin: to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria.
  • Colistin (Polymyxin E): to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria. Neisseria is colistin-resistant and thus grows in this medium.
  • Nystatin or anisomycin: to inhibit yeast.
  • Trimethoprim: to inhibit proteus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain over the forehead aggravated on bending and occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the urine. Her serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with cANCA positivity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It is characterized by the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), and kidneys (red cell casts).

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis.
  • Kidney (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity.

Options A and C: In Goodpasture's syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis, the symptoms of upper respiratory tract involvement are very rare.

Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is commonly seen in children. It presents with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: The following changes were observed on the administration of a drug. Which of the following is the likely drug?
questions.solution:
Since the administration of the given drug shows an increase in systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure, along with reflex bradycardia, the drug is likely to be norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine acts on α1 and β1 receptors to increase the peripheral vascular resistance and stroke volume respectively. This causes an increase in diastolic, systolic, and mean arterial pressure. Increased mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.


Epinephrine (option A) acts on α1, β1, and β2 receptors. There is a rise in systolic BP, but a fall in the diastolic BP — vascular β2 receptors are more sensitive than α1 receptors, leading to vasodilation. There is generally a small rise in the mean arterial pressure. The heart rate increases due to β1 action.

Isoproterenol (option D) acts on β receptors, causing predominantly β2 mediated vasodilation and resultant reflex tachycardia.

Propranolol (option C) is a β-blocker and will cause a decrease in the BP and heart rate.

questions.text: A term neonate is born to a primigravida with gestational diabetes. Periodic monitoring of blood glucose is done, though the baby is asymptomatic. The initial blood glucose was 25mg/dl, after which a trial of oral feed is given. The repeat blood glucose value is 35mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
In an asymptomatic baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes, if the blood glucose persists below 40mg/dl after a trial of oral feeds, the baby must be started on IV glucose infusion.

Infants of diabetic mothers are at a high risk of developing neonatal hypoglycemia. This is particularly applicable after the initial 2–3 hours of life. Blood sample is collected by heel prick. Babies showing blood glucose <40 mg/dL on a reagent strip should be treated for hypoglycemia. Since reagent strips have high false-positive rates, a confirmation of hypoglycemia by a lab test is recommended.

Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when blood glucose level is <45 mg/dL. Clinically, the hypoglycemia may be asymptomatic or may manifest with a range of clinical features like stupor, tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia and rarely, cardiac arrest.

In an asymptomatic baby, if the initial blood sugar is more than 20mg/dl, a trial of oral feeds is given, and blood sugar is tested after 30-45 minutes. If repeat blood sugar values are above 40 mg/dL, frequent feeding is ensured with 6 hourly monitoring of blood sugar for 48 hours. However, if blood sugar values persist below 40 m g /dL, the baby should receive an IV glucose infusion. 

If the initial blood sugar value is less than 20 mg/dL, then intravenous glucose infusion is started.

In a symptomatic baby, a bolus of 2 mL/kg of 10% dextrose should be given, followed immediately by glucose infusion at an initial rate of 6 mg/kg/min. Blood sugar is checked after 30-45 minutes and then 6 hourly. Repeat hypoglycemic episodes are treated by increasing the glucose infusion rate by 2 mg/kg/min until a maximum of 12 mg/kg/min.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with the lesions shown in the image. She also says that she has difficulty climbing the stairs and raising her arms above her head. The eyelids appear red in color. The probable diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
This image shows Gottron's papules, indicating a probable diagnosis of dermatomyositis, which is pathognomonic for this condition.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Gottron’s papules - erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discolouration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign, which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign- rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest
  • Nail bed telangiectasia
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands- non‐inflammatory hyperkeratosis occurring on the hands or feet, usually over the radial surfaces of the fingers and the outer border of the feet
  • Deposition of calcium in the tissues

 The image below shows heliotrope rash.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Yellow fever is endemic in India
Dengue virus has only one serotype
17D vaccine is used for yellow fever

questions.solution:
The 17D vaccine is a vaccine used for yellow fever.

The 17D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine derived from the Asibi strain. It is administered subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose starts 10 days after vaccination and lasts lifelong. It is thermolabile. This vaccine is mandatory in case of travel to or from endemic areas. Vaccination is contraindicated in

  • infants younger than 9 months of age
  • during pregnancy
  • in persons with egg allergies or altered immune systems

Other options:

Option A: Yellow fever does not exist in India. However, India has a large number of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes (the vector) and a large population of people who are non-immune. Strict vigilance is enforced on vaccination and quarantine for travel from endemic areas to prevent yellow fever from reaching India.

Option B: Dengue virus has four serotypes DEN 1-4 isolated from different parts of the world. 

  • DEN 1 from Hawaii
  • DEN 2 from New Guinea
  • DEN 3 and 4 from the Philippines

Option D: Kyasanur Forest disease is a type of tick-borne hemorrhagic fever. Infection is transmitted by the bite of ticks with monkeys as the amplifier host.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student with vision problems is referred for further evaluation of ectopia lentis. On examination, the patient is very tall, with long limbs and long, slender, spiderlike fingers. His chest has a caved-in appearance. A midsystolic click is heard, and an echo reveals mitral valve prolapse. What is the mode of inheritance of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan’s syndrome. It is an autosomal-dominant connective tissue disorder.

The condition results from heterozygous mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene located on chromosome 15. This encodes for the glycoprotein fibrillin which is a major building block of microfibrils. This constitutes the structural components of the suspensory ligament of the ocular lens and serves as substrates for elastin in the aorta and other connective tissues.

This syndrome has pleiotropic manifestations involving:

  • Ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation
  • Cardiovascular - mitral valve prolapse
  • Skeletal systems - long and slender limbs

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman receiving treatment for infertility presented with abdominal pain and distension. On examination, her pulse was 130/min, blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation was 97 %. Per abdominal examination revealed ascites, and no mass was palpable. Ultrasonography of the pelvis is shown below. Which of the following measures are ineffective in the prevention of this condition?

1. Withholding of FSH dose prior to hCG

2. Increasing the FSH dose

3. Substitution of FSH with hCG

4. Withholding the hCG trigger

5. Withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone, hCG-Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). The given sonogram reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts. Increasing FSH dose and withholding pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives have no role in preventing OHSS.

Strategies to avoid OHSS induction include :

  • Decreasing follicular stimulation - Decreasing the FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone) dose
  • Coasting- Withholding FSH administration for one or more days prior to the hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin) trigger injection 
  • Prophylactic treatment with volume expanders during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Substitution of hCG for FSH during the final days of ovarian stimulation.
  • Low-dose hCG administration- this supports the maturation of larger ovarian follicles but causes atresia of small antral follicles, reducing the risk of OHSS.
  • Withholding the hCG trigger - results in cycle cancellation. IVF should then be considered in this case.
  • GnRH antagonist protocol: This would allow a single dose of GnRH agonist in place of hCG. The resulting endogenous LH surge then brings about the maturation of the follicle and oocyte
  • Pretreatment with combined oral contraceptives is done to prevent cyst formation, improve the chances of ovulation induction, and reduce hyperstimulation.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

Option A- The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.

Option B- The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.

Option C- Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A patient who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy 3 days ago now presents with abdominal pain, guarding, and rigidity. USG shows a collection in the hepatorenal pouch. MRCP shows a complete transection of the common hepatic duct. Which of the following is the definitive management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The definitive management of a major bile duct injury such as transection of the common hepatic duct, identified in the postoperative period, is a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. 

Diagnosis of iatrogenic bile duct injury should be considered in any patient who presents with new-onset symptoms following cholecystectomy. Patients will usually present with abdominal pain, fever, jaundice, and features of peritonitis such as guarding and rigidity. Abdominal USG will show fluid collection. The immediate management is to drain the biliary collection by percutaneous drain insertion. MRCP is then done to evaluate the biliary tree and determine the injury's level and extent.

Biliary-enteric continuity is reestablished using Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. If the injury is high-up, near the hepatic duct bifurcation, or involves the intra-hepatic ducts, long-term stenting is done following Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy to improve patency rates.

If biliary tree injury is identified during the surgery, the management depends on the extent of the injury:

  • <50% circumference of the wall of the duct injured: managed by primary repair over a T-tube
  • >50% circumference of the wall of the duct injured: managed by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with altered sensorium, hydrophobia, and seizures after he was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient passed away and an autopsy was performed. Identify the layer of the cerebellar cortex in which the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies are usually seen.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of rabies encephalitis and the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies (Negri bodies) are seen in Purkinje cells belonging to the Purkinje cell layer (Layer C).

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers histologically. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer that contains stellate cells and basket cells, and dendrites of Purkinje cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It appears pale on H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - contain the cell bodies of the Purkinje cells which are flask-shaped. Characteristics of Purkinje cells:
    • Flask-shaped, evenly spaced cells arranged in a single layer.
    • The only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
    • A dendrite from the neck of each flask-shaped cell passes upward to the molecular layer and the axon passes down through the granular layer to the white matter.
    • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches from the T are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. It also contains Golgi cells that receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Rabies presents initially with fever and paraesthesia near the bite, following which the patient becomes increasingly anxious, leading to hydrophobia, delusions, and hallucinations. On microscopic examination of the brain, there is neuronal degeneration with inflammation. Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. (seen below)

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text:
A chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with bladder carcinoma. A CT scan showed cancer infiltration into the muscular layer. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

TURBT: transurethral resection of bladder tumor

choices.text: Radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for bladder cancer involving the muscular layer (muscle-invasive bladder carcinoma) is radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection.

Cigarette smoking is the main aetiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes and schistosomiasis. Patients present with painless gross hematuria and frequency and urgency of urine.

Diagnosis is made using cystourethroscopy. Blue-light cystoscopy is better able to delineate the areas in the bladder with suspicion of malignancy. CT urogram is used to assess the upper urinary tract and the presence of hydroureteronephrosis. It is also used to assess lymph nodal metastases. MRI of the bladder is useful in assessing whether or not the muscle layer of the bladder is involved. 

Depending on the invasion of the lamina propria and muscularis propria layers, the staging and management of bladder cancer varies, as given below:

Non-invasive papillary urothelial cancer Does not involve the lamina propria

TURBT only; patients are followed-up with cystoscopy
Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer Can involve lamina propria, but does not invade the muscularis propria

TURBT followed by postoperative mitomycin C instillation

Multifocal and high-grade tumors may progress to muscle invasive bladder cancer: radical cystectomy or intravesicle BCG should be considered
Muscle invasive bladder cancer Involves the muscularis propria

Radical cystectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy with urinary diversion

Radical external beam radiotherapy can be considered in patients unfit for surgery

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the surgery OPD with the following anomaly. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis suggests hypospadias. Bladder exstrophy is associated with epispadiasis, not hypospadiasis.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds. It is characterized by: 

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in dorsally hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias can be classified into the following types based on the meatal location:

  • Anterior (distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
    • Subcoronal
  • Middle
    • Distal penile
    • Midshaft
    • Proximal penile
  • Posterior (proximal)
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Surgery for correction of hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery for hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty: Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty: To reposition the urethral opening and tubularize urethra
  • Glanuloplasty: Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

questions.text: Which of the following methods is routinely used for the isolation of the bacteria?
questions.solution:
The method used for the isolation of the bacteria is streak culture.

Streak culture is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines in different segments of the plate. 

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.

Stab culture is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Stroke culture: It provides pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.

Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile Petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 

Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching them with a charged loop, pipettes, or syringes.

questions.text: A patient came to the ENT outpatient clinic with complaints of hearing loss and sensation of spinning while coughing, lifting heavy weights, and on exposure to loud sounds. He also describes that he is able to hear his eye movements and footsteps. There is a history of trauma a few weeks back. Pure-tone audiometry shows an air-bone gap. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome.

Here, the patients present with autophony (Hearing eye movements and footsteps), vertigo induced by loud sounds (Tullio's phenomenon), and Valsalva maneuvers, or by changes in pressure in the external auditory canal (Hennebert's sign). An air-bone gap in the audiometry represents conductive hearing loss.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals. Etiology may be congenital or acquired from cranial trauma.

Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis. Nystagmus triggered by sound or pressure, where the eye movements align in the same direction as the exposed semicircular canal, is a characteristic sign.

PTA shows a low-frequency conductive hearing loss. Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect, and the condition is usually treated by surgery if there are severe disabling symptoms. Otherwise, conservative medical management is done.

Other options:

Option A: Vestibular neuritis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating, and pallor. There should be no associated cochlear symptoms like hearing loss and tinnitus, neurological symptoms, or signs of brainstem lesions. 

Option B: Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Hennebert’s sign and Tullio's phenomenon are also seen in cases of Meniere's disease.

Option D: Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch.

questions.text:
A chronic smoker has finally decided to quit smoking after repeated arguments about it with his children. He tried quitting several times before without success and has come seeking medical help. Which of the following are proven to be useful in managing such cases?
  1. Varenicline
  2. Mirtazipine
  3. Bupropion
  4. Nicotine patch
  5. Behaviour therapy
questions.solution:
Bupropion, varenicline, nicotine replacement therapy, and behavior therapy are all used for smoking cessation. 

Drugs are only adjunctive to behavior therapy, which is the first line of management.

Behavior therapy is the most widely accepted and well-proven psychological therapy for treating tobacco use disorder. It consists of several techniques:

  • Skill training and relapse prevention
  • Stimulus control
  • Mindfulness approaches

Bupropion:

  • It enhances both noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission by inhibiting reuptake.
  • Used for aiding smoking cessation and for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs.
  • Side effects: seizures, sedation

Varenicline:

  • α4β2 Nicotinic ACh receptor partial agonist.
  • Used for smoking cessation.
  • Side effects: sleep disturbance, may depress mood and increase suicidal tendencies.

Mirtazapine:

  • Serotonin receptor antagonist.
  • Used for the treatment of depression in combination with SSRIs and for insomnia in depressive patients.
  • Side effect: sedation

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with complaints of redness and irritation of both eyes since 1 week. On examination, the following findings were observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image and the history suggest angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation limited to the conjunctiva and the lid margins near the angles. It is often accompanied by maceration of the surrounding skin.

The most common causative organism is Moraxella Axenfeld, which is responsible for the characteristic appearance of bacilli placed end to end, leading to the alternative name of diplobacillary conjunctivitis.

The source of infection is typically the nasal tract of healthy individuals or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation, discomfort, a history of dirty-white foamy discharge collection at the angles, and redness in the corner of the eyes.

Clinical signs of angular conjunctivitis include hyperemia (redness) of the bulbar conjunctiva near the canthi (corners of the eyes), hyperemia of the lid margins near the angles, skin irritation around the angles, and the presence of foamy mucopurulent discharge at the angles.

Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic enzymes.

Other options: Small, obligate intracellular, Gram-negative bacteria.

Option B: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornavirus namely enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid edema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Chlamydia are obligate intracellular organisms that do not grow on standard culture media such as blood agar. These organisms have two distinct forms: the extracellular elementary body, which is the infectious form, and the intracellular reticulate body, which forms inclusion bodies that can be visualized using iodine or Giemsa stain. Trachoma is caused by serovars A, B, and C of Chlamydia. In newborns born to infected mothers, Chlamydia can cause neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis.

Option D: Gonococcal conjunctivitis presents in the first week of life. The baby would have severe eyelid edema and purulent discharge. If allowed to progress, can rapidly cause corneal ulceration. It should be treated using third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come with a history of vaginal discharge. On examination, the discharge is thin, white in colour and has an unpleasant odour. The vaginal pH is 8.0 and a wet smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the alkaline pH of vaginal discharge (pH test ~ 8 ) and presence of clue cells on microscopy points towards the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Clue cells are epithelial cells with surfaces covered by adherent bacilli. Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days.

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is the most common cause of vaginitis. It is called vaginosis as it is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactoba­cilli with a 100-fold increase in growth of other anaerobic bacteriae like:

  • Haemophilus vaginalis
  • Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Mobiluncus
  • Peptococcus
  • Myco­plasma hominis

It is not sexually transmitted. Around 50% of women are asymptomatic carriers but a majority of the patients usually complain of thin grey malodorous vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, without itching.

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed if the vaginal discharge has 3 out of 4 characteristics mentioned in Amsel’s criteria.

  1. A homogeneous, thin, non-viscous, greyish-white discharge that smoothly adheres to the vaginal walls
  2. A vaginal pH > 4.5. (5-7 pH)
  3. A positive whiff test: An amine-like fishy odor is produced when a drop of 10% KOH is added to the sample of vaginal discharge
  4. The presence of >20% clue cells on the vaginal wet mount microscopy. The margins of the vaginal squamous epithelial cells are heavily studded with anaerobic bacteria such that the cell borders are poorly defined and nuclei are not visible. They are the most reliable indicators of bacterial vaginosis.

Nugent's score of ≥7 is diagnostic. It is used to count the number of Gardnerella vaginalis, mobilincus, and lactobacillus in the gram-stained smear or vaginal discharge.

The image below shows clue cells on the vaginal wet mount microscopy.

questions.text: A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd June 2023. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days in a calendar as shown below when he is supposed to take the vaccine.  Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?

choices.text: Updated Thai Red Cross regimen, intramuscular
Updated Thai Red Cross regimen, intradermal

questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Updated Thai red cross regimen which is intradermal.

The National Rabies Control Program recommends the use of the intradermal route for administering the rabies vaccine.

The Updated Thai Red Cross regimen (Intra-dermal) involves injecting 0.1 ml of reconstituted vaccine per ID site and on two sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28. (2-2-2-0-2). The first dose is given on day 0. It's important to note that the intradermal route is not recommended for individuals with compromised immune systems.

On the other hand, the Essen regimen (Intra-muscular) involves injecting either 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine into the deltoid muscle. It consists of a 5-dose regimen, with one dose given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28. (1,1,1,1,1)

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoids should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest feature in vitamin A deficiency?

choices.text: Loss of sensitivity to green light

questions.solution:
Loss of sensitivity to green light is the earliest feature of vitamin A deficiency while nyctalopia (night blindness) is the earliest symptom of vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can occur as carotenoids (most common - beta carotene from plant sources) or retinoids (from animal sources). Dietary sources of vitamin A are liver, fish, eggs, dark green, and deeply coloured fruits and vegetables.

3 forms of retinoids are:

  • Retinal is required mainly for normal vision (present in the visual pigment rhodopsin).
  • Retinol is important for the normal functioning of the reproductive system.
  • Retinoic acid has a role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.

The sequence of visual defects in vitamin A deficiency:

  1. Loss of sensitivity to green light
  2. Impairment of the eye to adapt to dim light
  3. Night blindness
  4. Bitot spots on the conjunctiva - white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera
  5. Prolonged deficiency of vitamin A → xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  6. If xerophthalmia is not treated, it results in keratomalacia (softening of the cornea), corneal ulceration, corneal scarring and ultimately complete blindness.

The image below shows a Bitot's spot which is pathognomic of vitamin A deficiency.

Other manifestations of vitamin A deficiency:

  • General impairment of immunity
  • Keratinization of skin (phrynoderma/toad skin)

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a history of accidental rupture of her partner's condom during intercourse. She is concerned about getting pregnant and wants to avoid it as she already has 2 kids. Which of the following contraceptives is the most effective to prevent unwanted pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most effective method of emergency contraception(post-coital contraceptive/ interceptive) is a copper IUCD. The failure rate is 0.1%.

The advantages of Copper T as an emergency contraceptive are as follows

  • It can be inserted as late as 5 days after the unprotected intercourse
  • It is cheap
  • The failure rate is 0.1%
  • It can remain as an ongoing contraceptive.

Other Options:

Option B: Ulipristal tablet has a 2% chance of pregnancy with its use.

Option C: Levonorgestrel tablet has a failure rate of 1.1%.

Option D: Mifepristone has a failure rate of 0.9%.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features and enlarging hands and feet. His height is above 2 standard deviations for his age. He also complains of headaches and visual problems. The parents complain about behavioural problems. There is an elevated level IGF-1 level for age and no suppression of GH  in a glucose tolerance test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests the cause to be pituitary gigantism. It is caused by the overproduction of growth hormone.  It is seen in younger age groups before the closure of epiphysis.

It is a rare condition, caused mostly by pituitary adenoma

Clinical features include-

  • Longitudinal growth acceleration secondary to GH excess.
  • Coarse facial features
  • Enlarging hands and feet
  • Rapid growth of the head can precede linear growth
  • Behavioral problems
  • Visual problems.
  • Delayed puberty.
  • Local effects- headache, visual field defects, and other hormone deficiencies.
  • Some cases also show acromegalic features.

GH levels are elevated. There is no normal suppression of GH levels induced by a glucose tolerance test. There are elevated levels of IGF-1 and IGFBP-3. MRI and CT imaging will show a pituitary adenoma.

The treatment options are surgical removal of well-circumscribed masses trans-sphenoidally or trans-cranially. Radiation and medical therapy may be required in some cases.

Medical Therapy-

  • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide and lanreotide suppress GH levels.
  • Bromocriptine and cabergoline can be when there is concomitant prolactin oversecretion. 
  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that causes effective suppression of IGF and GH levels.

Other options:

Option A: Overproduction of GH results in acromegaly which is seen in young adults after the closure of epiphyses. 

Option B: McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of the GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

Note: Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of nine years. 

Option C: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin, brittle skin with easy bruisability, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with carcinoma breast is planned for breast conservation surgery and oncoplasty. Which of the following statement is correct about this procedure?

choices.text: Volume displacement approach involves reconstruction using a distant flap
Oncoplasty is indicated for a small tumor to breast ratio
Volume replacement approach involves reconstruction using the remaining breast tissue
Oncoplasty is indicated when there is >20% volume loss of the breast tissue

questions.solution:
Volume loss >20% of the breast tissue is an indication for an oncoplastic procedure.

Oncoplastic breast conservation surgery (BCS) involves excising the tumor with wide margins followed by a repair of the defect which has been left behind in its place. This can be done by two methods:

  • Volume displacement approach (level I oncoplasty): involves the mobilization of the breast parenchyma itself and using it to fill the volume defect
  • Volume replacement approach (level II oncoplasty): involves the transposition of autologous tissues from elsewhere, such as flaps

Note that while conventional breast reconstruction follows total mastectomy, oncoplastic techniques are used following BCS. Volume loss >20% or a large tumor-to-breast ratio requires oncoplasty.

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

  • 1st-trimester pregnancy
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Persistently positive pathologic margin
  • Multicentric tumor
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

Relative contraindications:

  • Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with seizures. He was recently diagnosed with major depressive disorder and was prescribed an oral drug. The patient did not inform the treating psychiatrist about his past history of seizure disorder. Which of the following anti-depressants was most likely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug which was prescribed to this patient was bupropion. It decreases the seizure threshold and causes seizures — especially in patients with a history of seizure disorder or in overdose.

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that acts by increasing noradrenaline and dopamine transmission by inhibiting their reuptake by norepinephrine transporter and dopamine transporter. It is indicated in the treatment of major depression, prevention of seasonal affective disorder, and smoking cessation. The adverse effects of bupropion include anxiety, tachycardia and hypertension, irritability, and tremor. The most serious adverse is a lowering of seizure threshold.

Other options:

Option A: Buspirone is an anti-anxiety drug that acts by partial agonism at the 5HT1a receptors and antagonism at the dopamine receptors.

Option B: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It does not reduce the seizure threshold. The side effects of SNRIs include constipation, headache, and sexual dysfunction. Sudden stoppage of short-acting SNRIs such as venlafaxine has been associated with a discontinuation syndrome, which includes insomnia, nausea, vomiting, and vertigo. 

Option D: Sertraline is a selective serotonin receptor inhibitor (SSRI). It does not reduce the seizure threshold. The side effects of SSRIs include insomnia, anxiety, irritability, and sexual dysfunction. Short-acting SSRs such as paroxetine can also lead to discontinuation syndrome.

questions.text: Two patients, A and B, present with frequent nosebleeds. On further investigations, it is revealed that they have a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX and glycoprotein IIb–IIIa respectively. Which of the following lab tests will you order to confirm their diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ristocetin cofactor assay can be used to differentiate patient A who has Bernard–Soulier syndrome(deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor) from patient B who has Glanzmann's thrombasthenia(deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor).

This is because the ristocetin cofactor assay tests the integrity of the Gp Ib binding to the Von Willebrand factor. This will be normal in patients with Glanzmann's. So, this test can be used to differentiate Bernard–Soulier syndrome (abnormal ristocetin aggregation) from Glanzmann's thrombasthenia (normal ristocetin aggregation) .

Bernard–Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia are caused due to deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor and deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor respectively. In both these conditions, platelet count and PT/PTT is normal, with only an increase in bleeding time. 

Specific platelet aggregation tests with collagen, ADP, etc. will fail to bring about platelet aggregation in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia. Whereas, in Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation tests are normal.

Other options:

Option B: Platelet count is not specific enough to diagnose deficiencies of the mentioned glycoproteins.

Options C: Bleeding time assesses overall platelet function but does not directly diagnose the specific glycoprotein deficiencies.

Options D: PT/PTT are coagulation tests and can help identify clotting disorders but are not specific for glycoprotein deficiencies.

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling and tenderness over the anatomical snuffbox following an RTA. X-ray was performed which showed the following finding. Identify the false statement about this injury.

choices.text: Oblique x-ray view is preferred in recent fractures
Cast is applied in glass-holding position
Herbert screw is used for internal fixation

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and the x-ray are suggestive of scaphoid fracture. Nonunion is a common complication of this condition, while malunion is rare.

Scaphoid fracture characteristically presents with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox following a fall on an outstretched hand.

  • Wrist osteoarthritis

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of recurrent abortions. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions, all of them <10 weeks of gestation. On examination, the right calf was swollen and tender. Lab investigations are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Platelets - 80,000 cells/ cumm

D-dimers - 600 ng/ml

Lupus anticoagulant antibody - Positive

Anti-cardiolipin antibody - Positive
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA).

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical (obstetric or vascular) criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Vascular criteria: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Patients testing positive for lupus anticoagulant may not have systemic lupus erythematosus [SLE], anticardiolipin antibody, and anti β2 glycoprotein antibodies. Based on this, the types of APLA include:

  • Without associated SLE - Primary antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • With associated SLE - Secondary antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

Patients with antiphospholipid antibodies may develop venous and arterial thromboses, which may be associated with:

  • Recurrent spontaneous miscarriages
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Focal cerebral or ocular ischemia

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and vomiting since last night. On examination, tenderness is present. USG shows thickened gall bladder wall with peri-cholecystic fluid and posterior acoustic shadows. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given patient with uncomplicated calculous cholecystitis, the best management would be early laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

In a patient with cholelithiasis, the gallstones block the cystic duct and cause stagnation of bile, leading to inflammation, edema, and superadded infection. This scenario is called acute calculous cholecystitis. Thus, the main pathophysiology behind acute calculous cholecystitis is unresolved blockade of the cystic duct.

The patient presents with fever, pain, and tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. There is an arrest of inspiration on palpating under the right costal margin — this is known as Murphy's sign. Jaundice is absent. If present, it should raise the suspicion of cholangitis or Mirizzi syndrome. The diagnosis can be confirmed with USG. Gallstones can be seen with posterior acoustic shadowing. Acute cholecystitis is indicated by gall bladder wall thickening and the presence of peri-cholecystic fluid. In atypical cases, a HIDA scan may be used to make the diagnosis.

Patients with acute cholecystitis are kept NPO and started on parenteral antibiotics. Cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice for acute cholecystitis. The surgery can be performed laparoscopically with good outcomes within the first week of the disease process. Previously the patients were managed non-operatively during their initial hospitalization and cholecystectomy was done 6 weeks later (option B). But early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the norm now if the patient presents early. 

Patients with very-high operative risk, such as those with end-organ dysfunction (grade III in Tokyo classification), are treated with percutaneous cholecystostomy (option C). This procedure drains the infected bile and results in the improvement of patients' symptoms. A delayed cholecystectomy is done after physiological optimization.

questions.text:
A young adult male presented with chronic fatigue and gallstones. His father had a similar illness for which splenectomy was done. Investigations were done and shown below. Which of the following protein defects is not seen in this condition?

Hemoglobin- decreased
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased
Mean corpuscular volume - decreased
Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations and peripheral smear showing numerous spherocytes are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Laminins form part of the basement membrane which binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments. Mutations in laminin and laminin alpha 2 (merosin) result in the blistering phenotype of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) and congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) respectively.  

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene result in the most severe form of HS.

 

Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. They show normocytic normochromic anemia, an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration, raised RDW(red cell distribution width) and normal or reduced MCV (mean corpuscular volume).

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia and hemosiderosis.

Splenectomy is the current treatment of choice in HS.
