questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of groin swelling. On examination, a  globular swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle is seen. No tenderness or redness is present. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Lacunar ligament prevents the reduction of the sac
Sac lies lateral to femoral vein
There is high risk of strangulation

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a groin swelling present lateral and below the pubic tubercle is suggestive of a femoral hernia. Femoral hernia traverses the femoral canal, which lies medial to the femoral vein.

A femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in females. It will pass through the femoral ring proximally to enter the femoral canal. Femoral canal is bound by femoral vein laterally, inguinal ligament anteriorly, and pelvic bone with iliopectineal ligament (Cooper's) and lacunar ligament (Gimbernat's) medially. Lacunar ligament has a sharp unyielding edge that prevents the reduction of the femoral hernia. The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and the rigidity of the femoral ring.

All patients with unexplained bowel obstruction should be examined properly for a femoral hernia. Surgery is the only treatment for femoral hernia, and these patients should be treated on priority because of the high risk of strangulation. The surgical approaches which are used are:

  • Low approach (Lockwood): suitable when there is no risk of strangulation; bowel can't be inspected and resected in this approach
  • Inguinal approach (Lotheissen)
  • High approach (McEvedy): suitable for emergency situations when the risk of bowel strangulation is high
  • Laparoscopic approach: both TEP and TAPP approaches can be used; the laparoscopic approach is recommended in women

  • Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

  • Lateral to femoral artery

  • Behind the femoral vessels

  • Infront of femoral vessels

  • Through saphenous opening

questions.text: A 25-year-old rape victim was brought by the lady constable to the gynaecologist for examination. Which of the following tests need to be performed on her vaginal sample to identify it as semen?

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Fetal head compression typically shows early deceleration.

A sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions:

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal hemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection, and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR and in most cases the onset of the uterine contraction and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation)

 Late deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR. It begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. Nadir occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration:

It is the intermittent periodic slowing (variable) of FHR with rapid onset and recovery. Decelerations are variable in all respect of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing to the uterine contractions. It is thought to indicate cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. Accelerations often precede and follow the deceleration.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with a rash that was insidious in onset and is mildly itchy. Following Wood's lamp examination, it is diagnosed as pityriasis versicolor. Which of the following is characteristic of the causative agent on microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species. It shows spaghetti and meatballs appearance on microscopic examination of skin scrapings.

Pityriasis versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They are mildly itchy if at all and have fine scales that are branny/furfuraceous. Under Wood's lamp examination, the lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence. The Malassezia species causing this are lipophilic fungi. They cause the degradation of lipids and produce acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor are-

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

On KOH mount and microscopy, the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ appearance or ‘bananas and grapes’ appearance. 

The image attached below shows the classic spaghetti and meatballs appearance on KOH mount.

Other options: 

Option A: Medlar bodies are sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls are observed in chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Dermatophytes such as Epidermophyton, Microsporum, and Trichosporon have asexual spores called microconidia and macroconidia on a culture mount.

Option D: Yeasts with pseudohyphae are characteristic of Candida. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Which of the following statements would not apply to a drug with low volume of distribution?

choices.text: It can be effectively removed by hemodialysis
It is predominantly present in extravascular compartment

questions.solution:
A drug with a low volume of distribution (Vd) is likely to be present predominantly in the intravascular compartment, not extravascular. 

Vd refers to the volume that would accommodate the entire drug in the body, if the concentration was the same as in plasma. Vd is governed by the lipid solubility and charge of the drug, the degree of the plasma protein binding, and the affinity of the drug for the different tissues of the body. Apparent Vd can also be altered by liver and kidney diseases because of how they influence plasma protein binding.

A high Vd is seen with drugs that are extensively bound to body tissues, and small lipophilic drugs which can easily cross over to the extravascular compartment. 

A low Vd is seen with drugs that have extensive plasma protein binding, and large charged (hydrophilic) drugs that remain restricted to the intravascular compartment. Since drugs with low Vd are restricted to the intravascular compartment, it is relatively easy to remove them by hemodialysis in case of poisoning.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is in her 8th week of gestation presents with an increased frequency of vomiting which is associated with retching. She shows no signs of dehydration or volume depletion. Which of the following options would you suggest in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient presents with hyperemesis gravidarum. Mild to moderate symptoms of hyperemesis gravidarum can be treated with a combination of doxylamine and vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) which is approved for nausea and vomiting associated with pregnancy.

The antihistamine effect of doxylamine can contribute to the anti-emetic effect. The mechanism of action of pyridoxine is not known but shows a synergistic action with doxylamine. 

Unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis, or hypokalemia is known as hyperemesis gravidarum. It is most commonly seen in a first pregnancy, young age, low body mass, history of migraine/motion sickness, positive family history, hydatidiform mole, low body mass, and multi-fetal gestation

The pathophysiology includes an increase in human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and estrogen levels. Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter during pregnancy due to the elevations in estrogen and progesterone. This leads to an increased incidence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms in pregnancy, and one symptom of GERD is nausea.

Symptoms include vomiting which is increased in frequency with retching. Epigastric pain, oliguria, and constipation may occur.
Signs include features of dehydration and ketoacidosis: Dry coated tongue, sunken eyes, acetone smell in breath, tachycardia, and hypotension.

Complications
Maternal

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy, beriberi due to thiamine deficiency
  • Pontine myelinolysis
  • Peripheral neuritis
  • Korsakoff’s psychosis
  • Stress ulcer in the stomach
  • Mallory- Weiss syndrome
  • Jaundice, hepatic failure
  • Convulsions and coma
  • Hypoprothrombinemia due to vitamin K deficiency
  • Renal failure

Fetal - Low birth weight

Management of hyperemesis gravidarum: 

  • Mild to moderate symptoms can be treated with dietary modifications, vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine.
  • Severe cases need IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral ondansetron/metoclopramide/promethazine. (Option D)
  • Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV  is given in case of hypotension or in intractable vomiting. Oral prednisolone is also used in severe cases. (Option A and B)

The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

The cerebral aqueduct is a small, approximately circular tube with a diameter of 1-2 mm. It runs along the midline of the dorsal quarter of the midbrain, surrounded by the periaqueductal (central) grey matter. At the rostral end, it starts just below the posterior commissure and connects to the caudal aspect of the third ventricle. At the caudal end, it continues into the fourth ventricle, located at the junction of the midbrain and pons. In children with von Recklinghausen's disease, primary aqueductal stenosis is a characteristic feature.

 

Other options:

Option A - The third ventricle is connected to the lateral ventricles via the interventricular foramina of Monro on either side.

questions.text: A patient planned for spinal surgery is placed in the prone position. Which of the following complications is unlikely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Potential complications which can occur in a patient who has been placed in prone position include:

  • Brachial plexus injury
  • Shoulder dislocation
  • Facial trauma, including blindness due to vascular congestion of the eye
  • Pressure necrosis of breasts, external genitalia and pressure-bearing bony prominences
  • Displacement of the endotracheal tube

Prone position is used in spinal surgery and certain procedures such as extralevator abdominoperineal resection for rectal cancer. Specially designed pillows with a hollow to accommodate the face and endotracheal tube are used. Toes are elevated off the bed by placing pads under the shins.

Some important complications of other surgical positions are:

  • Supine: ulnar, axillary, peroneal, and brachial neurapraxia, pressure necrosis of heels and sacral region
  • Lateral: preferential ventilation of one lung can cause respiratory compromise, traction injury of brachial plexus, corneal abrasion, and ocular trauma
  • Lithotomy: venous and arterial insufficiency (option D), digital amputation at the edge of the bed, sciatic nerve injury, saphenous and peroneal neurapraxia

questions.text: Identify the fetal presentation shown in the following image :
questions.solution:
The image depicts anterior asynclitism where the anterior parietal bone is the presenting part.

The image shows the spine (dorsal part of the maternal body) and the pubic symphysis bone (ventral part of the maternal body) and it shows sagittal suture of the fetus deflected posteriorly towards the sacrum, thus making the anterior parietal bone the presenting part at the vaginal introitus.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder, causing the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

When the sagittal suture is deflected posteriorly, towards the sacral promontory the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

When the sagittal suture is deflected anteriorly, towards the symphysis, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism. With extreme posterior asynclitism, the posterior ear may be easily palpated.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labour. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.

questions.text: A woman has a ​blood glucose level of 320 mg/dL and a GFR of 110 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum for glucose is 300mg/min?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 52 mg/min.

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 110 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 320 mg/dL= 3.2mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 110 ml/min x 3.2 mg/ml
                               = 352 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question, the transport maximum is 300 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose – total reabsorbed glucose (transport maximum for glucose)

  = 352 – 300 mg/min
  = 52 mg/min

The renal threshold for glucose is the plasma level at which the glucose first appears in the urine. If all the tubules in the nephron worked at a given time, then the renal threshold would be 300mg/dL, that is, 375 mg/min (TmG) divided by 125 mL/min (GFR). However, the actual renal threshold is 200mg/dL. This is because, at a given time, not all tubules are reabsorbing the glucose. This deviation in the actual renal threshold from the calculated renal threshold is called renal splay.

The normal transport maximum in males is 375mg/min and in females is 300mg/min.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy developed psoriatic lesions as seen in the image below following a bout of beta-hemolytic streptococcal tonsillitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic lesions as seen in the image following a bout of beta-hemolytic streptococcal tonsillitis in a child are suggestive of guttate psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. Guttate psoriasis is a type of psoriasis occurring as a sudden onset shower of small lesions seen diffusely over the body, more on the trunk and proximal limbs. It is more common in children and young adults, following infection with group A streptococcus, and is often the first presentation of psoriasis. It can also occur as a flare-up in adults with plaque psoriasis that began in childhood. Lesions usually resolve over about 3 months. Some patients with acute guttate psoriasis might develop plaque psoriasis in the future.

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials - Recurrent episodes may be related to the pharyngeal carriage of the responsible streptococcus by the patient or close contact. A course of semisynthetic penicillin with rifampin may be required to clear chronic streptococcal carriage.
  • Phototherapy - Broad-band ultraviolet B (UVB)- Response is better with broadband UVB over narrow-band UVB. 

Other options:

Option A: Inverse psoriasis or flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Option B: Pustular psoriasis is the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions which may be generalized or localized. 

Option D: Plaque psoriasis or discoid psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text:
What is the mechanism of action of the poison obtained from the seeds shown in the image below?

VAMP- Vesicle-associated membrane protein

GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid

ACh- Acetylcholine

choices.text: Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors
Blocking glycine receptors in the ventral horn

questions.solution:
The seeds of Strychnos nux vomica are shown in the given image. The poison obtained from these seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem.

Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features. These include:

  • Tonic-clonic seizures
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension)
  • Risus sardonicus
  • Other less common postures that can be seen are emprosthotonus (body bent forward as if bowing) and pleurosthotonus (body bent sideward). 

Strychnos nux vomica seeds are toxic only when chewed/ crushed prior to swallowing. Intact seeds, if swallowed, will not result in any further symptoms. Treatment involves an initial stomach wash and the use of activated charcoal to absorb the ingested poison. The patient should be treated with benzodiazepines or barbiturates to control seizures, and they should be placed in a dark room to avoid triggering further convulsions.

Other options: 

Option (A)- Blocking peripheral postsynaptic ACh receptors can be seen in curare poisoning. It can cause progressive flaccid paralysis, ultimately leading to respiratory failure. It was used as an arrow poison during wars in the past.

Option (B)- Blocking peripheral and central ACh receptors can be seen in datura poisoning. It acts by competitive antagonism. All the parts of the datura plant are poisonous. It shows predominantly peripheral anticholinergic effects like flushed face, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils, delirium, urinary retention, etc. with central effects like psychosis and delirium.

Option (C)- VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein) cleavage in GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) neurons at the ventral horn of the spinal cord, is the mechanism of action of toxins in tetanus infections. VAMP is normally responsible for the release of GABA, hence VAMP cleavage results in unopposed muscular contractions. The resulting clinical features are very similar to that of strychnine poisoning. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following would not prompt surgical treatment in a patient diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
Increased frequency of micturition alone is not an indication of surgery in the case of BPH. 

Indications of surgical treatment include:

  • Acute retention of urine in fit men with no other cause for retention
  • Chronic retention and renal impairment:
    • Residual urine of ≥200 mL 
    • Raised blood urea
    • Hydroureter or hydronephrosis
  • Complications of bladder outflow obstruction:
    • Stone
    • Infection
    • Diverticula formation
  • Recurrent hematuria with no obvious cause
  • Severe symptoms not responding to drug therapy

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common benign prostatic disease in men above 50 years. It arises from the inner aspect of the prostate gland, the transitional zone. It is characterized by benign, hyperplastic proliferation of prostatic stroma and epithelial elements. This overgrowth is stimulated by dihydrotestosterone. This growth progressively compresses the urethra, resulting in obstructive urinary symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated. Pressure flow urodynamic studies are done to estimate the flow rate and a severe reduction in flow rate is an indication for surgery.

The first line management for BPH is pharmacological therapy using drugs such as alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Alpha-adrenergic blockers tend to provide symptomatic relief quickly, while 5α-reductase inhibitors take about 6 months to reduce the size of the prostate.

Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is the most commonly performed surgical procedure for the management of BPH. Tissue strips are cut from the bladder neck, down to the verumontanum using electrocautery. The duration of resection is limited to one hour when 1% glycine is used as the irrigating fluid. When the growth is quite large, an open simple prostatectomy is performed.

Note: Most carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone and may be palpable as nodular enlargement of prostate during the digital examination of the rectum.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with severe headache, blurring of vision, and oliguria. Examination reveals BP of 200/100mmHg and papilledema. Skin thickening is noted over his hands, with contractures in the wrist and fingers. Which of the following antibodies is least likely to be found in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of accelerated hypertension, oliguria along with scleroderma is suggestive of scleroderma renal crisis. Anti-centromere antibody is least likely to be found in this patient as patients with anti-centromere antibodies are protected from this complication.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency characterized by acute onset malignant hypertension and kidney failure, usually in the absence of previous evidence of significant kidney disease. The use of steroids is associated with an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis.

Clinical features of scleroderma renal crisis are:

  • Accelerated hypertension - headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, hypertensive retinopathy, and hypertensive encephalopathy.
  • Acute kidney injury - oliguria, mild proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, renal failure.
  • Pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), thrombocytopenia.

Risk factors for scleroderma renal crisis include African-American race, male sex, and diffuse or progressive skin involvement. Up to 50% of patients with scleroderma renal crisis have anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, whereas patients with anti-centromere antibodies appear to be protected from this complication.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) (Option 1) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis. 
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody (Option 2)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option 2)
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody (Option 4)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency and should be treated with angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, and direct renin inhibitors. Glucocorticoids should be used at a low dose only when necessary.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male with a history of recurrent painful oral aphthous ulcers that usually subside in about 10 days without leaving a scar and recurrent painful scrotal ulcers that heal with scarring has a positive pathergy test. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features of recurrent oral and genital ulcers along with a positive pathergy test are suggestive of Behcet's disease.

Behcet's syndrome is a vasculitic disorder that presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations and ocular involvement. It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder with a known association with HLA B*51. 

This syndrome commonly presents in young people, with males having more severe disease. These patients present with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers that are usually small and painful, painful genital ulcers, skin lesions (folliculitis, erythema nodosum, positive pathergy test, etc.), uveitis, arthritis/arthralgia, deep vein thromboses, etc.

Diagnostic Criteria of Behçet’s Syndrome:

Recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following:

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions
  • Positive Pathergy test

Pathergy reaction is a hypersensitivtiy reaction of the skin 24 to 48 hours following a prick with a needle. There is formation of papular or pustular nodules at the site of prick which is indicative of a positive test.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after blunt trauma to the chest. ECG of the patient shows the following findings. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Initial management is by needle pericardiocentesis followed by definitive sternotomy or lateral thoracotomy.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Clinical presentation -

  • Acute cardiac tamponade - Within minutes, due to trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Presents as cardiogenic shock.
  • Subacute cardiac tamponade - occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis. Symptoms include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 
  • Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of :
    • hypotension
    • muffled heart sounds, and 
    • elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent

 

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. Definitive management includes emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy (Option A and B). In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Option D: The definitive treatment for tension pneumothorax is tube thoracostomy preferably in the fourth intercostal space at the anterior axillary line. Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper resonance on percussion on the affected side. These signs are not observed in a patient with cardiac tamponade. The three most important findings to diagnose tension pneumothorax are respiratory distress, hyper-tympany on percussion, and decreased lung sounds.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for follow-up evaluation in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis is ______________ .
questions.solution:
Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) is the investigation of choice for follow-up evaluation in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis. Failure of nontreponemal test titers to decrease fourfold within 12-24 months after therapy depending on the stage of syphilis (inadequate serologic response) might be indicative of treatment failure.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis - RPR or VDRL
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibodies to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy - RPR or VDRL
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test - FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA 
  • RPR - Rapid plasma reagin test
  • FTA-ABS - Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test 
  • TPHA - Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay 
  • EIA - Enzyme immunoassay
  • CIA - Chemiluminescence immunoassay

VDRL test is a slide flocculation test used widely for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

In this test, the serum is inactivated at 56°C for 30 minutes and a measured volume of serum is placed on a special cavity slide. The cardiolipin antigen after preparation is added to the serum sample on a slide and is rotated on a VDRL rotator for a specified period of 4 minutes. In a positive test, the cardiolipin antigen reacts with reagin antibodies present in the infected serum and forms visible clumps. In a negative test, cardiolipin continues to remain as uniform crystals in the serum.

The result of the test is reported as reactive, weak reactive, or nonreactive depending on the extent of the formation of the clumps. The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1–2 weeks after the appearance of the chancre. It is a highly sensitive test and the sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of the disease:-

  • The test is 60–75% sensitive in primary syphilis
  • The test is 100% sensitive in secondary syphilis
  • High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascular or cardiovascular complications.
  • The test is usually negative in the tertiary stage of syphilis
  • This test is negative in early primary syphilis, latent acquired syphilis, and late congenital syphilis

Other options:

Option A: Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is an indirect immunofluorescence test used to detect specific treponemal antibodies. It is not available for routine testing as it is done only in suitably equipped labs.

Option C: Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test detects the presence of treponemal antibodies in the serum. Similar to the FTA-ABS test, it is also not available for routine testing.

Option D: Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with complains of pain and inability to move the limb following a fall on an outstretched hand. A diagnosis of anterior shoulder dislocation was made. The following method of reduction is performed. What is the step 'C' performed in the given technique?
questions.solution:
The shown maneuver above is Kocher's technique of anterior shoulder reduction, The step 'C' here signifies Adduction being done.

The order of steps in Kocher's maneuver is traction, external rotation, adduction, medial rotation (TEAM) shown as steps A, B, C, and D respectively.

Other maneuvers used in anterior dislocation of the shoulder include:

  • Stimson’s gravity method: The patient is made to lie prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. A weight may be attached to the elbow or wrist. The shoulder may reduce after 15-20 minutes. 
  • Hippocratic method (traction counter-traction): Gently increasing traction is applied to the arm with the shoulder in slight abduction.  Counter-traction is applied with the heel in the axilla.

Anterior dislocation is the most common among shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hands.The clinical features include severe pain and the patient usually supports his dislocated arm with the opposite arm. 

The following findings are seen on examination:

  • Flattening of the normal shoulder contour.
  • A displaced head can be felt as a fullness below the clavicle.
  • Dugas test and Hamilton ruler test are positive. 

X-ray findings in anterior shoulder dislocation

Hill Sach's lesion is due to impingement of glenoid labrum into the humeral head, causing posterolateral depression.

Bankart lesion is due to stripping of the glenoid labrum from the glenoid cavity as the head dislocates. It sometimes may be associated with bony avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid rim as seen in this image.

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with severe abdominal pain which occurs around half an hour after taking food. He reports weight loss over the last 2 months. The patient is a known diabetic and smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. Which of the following investigations will be the most helpful in establishing the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given history of abdominal pain occurring half an hour after food with associated weight loss, in a diabetic patient who is a current smoker, points to a diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia. The best investigation to establish this diagnosis is CT angiography.

Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of superior mesenteric artery and coeliac trunk. Patients present with recurrent episodes of acute, dull abdominal pain 30 minutes to 1 hour following food intake. This pain is termed as intestinal angina. Often the patients report chronic diarrhea and weight loss due to malabsorption.

CT angiography remains the best investigation to assess the degree of atherosclerotic blockade of the vessel. Duplex ultrasound has also been shown to have good sensitivity and specificity as a screening investigation. Treatment is by angioplasty of the affected vessel. Bypass surgery is done if a longer vessel length is involved or if there is severe calcification.

questions.text: A 17-year-old swimmer presents to your OPD with blurred vision and severe pain in the left eye. On slit-lamp examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion is seen. Paracentesis reveals the following finding. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a swimmer with a ring-shaped lesion of the cornea and the image depicting cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis. Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% is the most useful drug in the treatment of this condition.

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes.

It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub while wearing contact lenses, the homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standing groundwater etc.
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern
  • Investigation
    • Staining: Calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
    • Culture: Non-nutrient agar with Escherichia coli overlay

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal Microscopy- may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Histopathology- double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff.
  • Culture: Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. Coli plated on a non-nutrient agar.

 Treatments for this condition include:

  • Diamidines
    • Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %)
    • Hexamidine
  • Aminoglycosides
    • Neomycin
    • Paromycin
  • Imidazoles
    • Clotrimazole
    • Miconazole

Combination therapy with chlorhexidine and polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the most effective against trophozoites and cysts and are recommended as the first line of therapy. Debridement may be warranted in certain conditions.

Chronic refractory cases may require corneal transplantation and unresponsive cases might need to be managed with enucleation. 

The first image shows the ring lesions seen in acanthamoeba keratitis while the second image shows double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with the advanced brain disease. The third image shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts wall of acnathamoeba on plain mount. 

 

Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option 1) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis and spring catarrh which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option 2) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Doxycycline (Option 3) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents with an ulcerative vulval lesion that bleeds. Biopsy confirms a diagnosis of vulvar carcinoma. The gynecologist is concerned about the involvement of lymph nodes. Which nodes are usually the first to be involved in such cases?
questions.solution:
The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are usually the first to be involved in vulvar carcinoma.

Vulval cancer is generally seen in elderly women and they present with vulvar pruritus, vulvar swelling, lump, or an ulcer. The lump is papular with a raised pigmented area. The ulcers have often everted margins with fissured, cracked, and indurated surrounding skin. They usually bleed and cause offensive vulval discharge. The lesions are most commonly seen over the labia major.  HPV or HIV infection, diabetes, hypertension, and obesity are associated with vulval cancers. 

The order of lymph node involvement in vulval cancer includes mainly the superficial inguinal lymph node, deep inguinal lymph node, and femoral group of lymph nodes. The external iliac, obturator, and common iliac nodes are also involved in the advanced stages.

Surgical morbidity in early vulval cancer can be reduced by restricting unnecessary lymph node dissection but it is necessary for the determination of the extent of primary lymph node (sentinel) involvement. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (frozen section) before or during surgery help to attain an adequate surgical procedure with a good prognosis.

Mapping is done by:

  • Intraoperative intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor has reported a detection rate of 100%
  • Localization of radioactive tracer-labeled tissue with a hand-held detector
  • Lymphoscintigraphy also gives a 100% detection rate

For the treatment of vulval cancer in young women, conservative ablative surgery, as well as wide local excision, is adequate. A simple vulvectomy is performed in elderly women. Radical vulvectomy is recommended in patients with regional lymph node involvement.

The prognosis depends upon the lymph node status.

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A 58-year-old white man presents with a 6-month history of productive cough, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. The chest radiograph shows a cluster of grape appearance. A biopsy shows features of a non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) infection. Cystic fibrosis is ruled out. Which of the following drugs is not to be used in the treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to an NTM infection. Mucolytic dornase (DNase) is not used in the treatment regimen of this case.

Mucolytic dornase is recommended routinely in cystic fibrosis (CF)-related bronchiectasis but not in non-CF bronchiectasis.

Treatment of bronchiectasis

  • Antibiotic treatment targeting the causative pathogen (most common: H. influenzae and P. aeruginosa) should be administered for a minimum of 10–14 days.
  • NTM infection: a macrolide (clarithromycin and azithromycin) combined with rifampin and ethambutol.
  • Mucolytic administration: The mucolytic dornase (DNase) is recommended routinely in CF-related bronchiectasis, but not in non-CF bronchiectasis, given concerns about potential harm in the non-CF population.
  • Bronchial hygiene.
  • Hydration.
  • Aerosolization of bronchodilators.
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g., hypertonic saline).
  • Chest physiotherapy.
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation.
  • Refractory cases: Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents to the ER following a road traffic accident. His respiratory rate is 28/min and BP is 80/50 mmHg. Cyanosis and inspiratory stridor are present. He has an open fracture of the shaft of the femur. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain IV access to begin fluids
Reduce the shaft of the femur fracture
Endotracheal intubation and cervical spine restriction
Tube thoracostomy in the right hemithorax

questions.solution:
Since the given patient has signs of airway compromise such as cyanosis and tachypnea, the most appropriate next step would be endotracheal intubation and cervical spine restriction.

The primary survey consists of the following ABCDEs:

  • Airway maintenance with restriction of cervical spine motion
  • Breathing and ventilation
  • Circulation and hemorrhage control
  • Disability (assessment of neurologic status)
  • Exposure and environment control

This sequence is based on the degree of threat to life that can be caused by various injuries and must always be adhered to. Therefore, the most life-threatening abnormality has to be addressed first. For example, regardless of the cause of airway compromise, the airway has to be managed on priority because a compromised airway will rapidly kill the patient. 

If the patient is able to communicate verbally, the airway is unlikely to be compromised. Objective signs of airway obstruction include agitation, cyanosis, stridor, displaced trachea, and use of accessory muscles of respiration. If there is any doubt regarding the patient's ability to maintain a patent airway, a definitive airway should be established. This can be in the form of endotracheal intubation, orotracheal airway, or surgical airway (cricothyroidotomy or tracheostomy). Other indications for definitive airway include:

  • Impending airway compromise — following inhalational injury, facial fractures or retropharyngeal hematoma
  • Inability to maintain adequate oxygenation by facemask oxygen supplementation
  • Presence of apnea
  • Glasgow Coma Scale [GCS] score of 8 or less
  • Prevention of aspiration of blood or vomitus

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
Which of the following disorders falls under the obsessive-compulsive spectrum of disorders according to DSM-V?
  1. Skin picking disorder
  2. Factitious disorder
  3. Body dysmorphic disorder
  4. Trichotillomania
  5. Oppositional defiant disorder
questions.solution:
Among the given options skin picking disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, and trichotillomania fall under obsessive-compulsive and related disorders according to DSM-V.

Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders:

It refers to a group of disorders that are characterized by repetitive thoughts and behaviors that share similar etiologies and important diagnostic validators. Important features of these disorders are obsessions, intrusive thoughts, and preoccupations. It includes:

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder - It is characterized by repetitive and intrusive thoughts that are unwelcome (obsessions) or repetitive behaviors that the person feels compelled to do (compulsions) or both.
  • Body dysmorphic disorder - This is characterized by marked distress about an imagined or slight defect in appearance which keeps the patient preoccupied.
  • Hoarding disorder - It is a behavioral pattern where a person has the compulsion of accumulating items that may or may not have any use to the person.
  • Trichotillomania or Hair-pulling disorder - Noticeable hair loss that may occur anywhere on the body caused by repeated hair pulling is seen in this disorder.
  • Excoriation or Skin-picking disorder - Damage caused to one's skin as a result of the compulsive need to pick at it.
  • Substance/ Medication-induced obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder due to another medical condition
  • Others - Obsessional jealousy

Other options:

Factitious disorder belongs to "Somatic Symptom and Related Disorders" where physical or psychological symptoms are deliberately feigned to fall sick. It is also known as Munchausen syndrome.

Oppositional defiant disorder falls under the spectrum of "Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorders" where children and adolescents exhibit symptoms of anger, irritability, defiance, and refusal to comply with regulations

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She complains of blurring of vision in one of the eyes soon after she comes home after her zumba classes. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
The blurring of vision after a physical exercise in multiple sclerosis is Uhthoff's Phenomenon. 

Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.

Other options:

Option A: Lhermitte's sign is an electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.

Option C: Facial myokymia is a persistent, rapid flickering contraction of the facial musculature or a contraction that slowly spreads across the face. It results from lesions of the corticobulbar tracts or in the course of the facial nerve in the brainstem.

Option D: Tic douloureux is the other name for trigeminal neuralgia. It can occur when the demyelinating lesion involves the root entry (or exit) of the fifth cranial nerve.

questions.text: The following colony morphology on blood agar is indicative of
questions.solution:
The given image shows the frosted glass appearance of the colonies, which is characteristic of Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is the etiologic agent of anthrax—a common disease of livestock and, occasionally, of humans—and the only obligate pathogen within the genus Bacillus. It is a gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. Culture characteristics are as follows:

  • On agar, irregularly round colonies are formed, 2 to 3 mm in diameter, raised, dull, opaque, greyish white, with a frosted glass appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.
  • On gelatin stab, they appear as inverted fir tree appearance.
  • On solid media with penicillin, they show a string of pearls appearance in culture smear.

questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in cataract formation in a patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Aldose reductase is the enzyme involved in cataract formation in a diabetic patient.

The polyol pathway has been implicated in the formation of diabetic cataracts. This pathway results in the production of fructose from glucose and, sorbitol is formed as an intermediate. Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. 

Diabetics have increased glucose levels in the lens, peripheral nerves, and renal glomeruli which are not insulin sensitive. This increases the activity of aldose reductase in these tissues. The sorbitol so formed accumulates in the lens leading to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

Options B and C are enzymes of galactose metabolism. Classical galactosemia is caused by deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).  Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain. Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Only cataract is seen in the deficiency of this enzyme because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed. Hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. 

Option D:  Aldolase B is the enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate in fructose metabolism. A deficiency of this causes hereditary fructose intolerance.

questions.text: A patient who comes with a history of an insect bite while trekking is diagnosed to have scrub typhus. The weil-Felix reaction will show positivity for which of the following antigens?
questions.solution:
The Weil–Felix reaction for scrub typhus shows positivity for OX K.

Weil–Felix test is a heterologous agglutination test used for the diagnosis of rickettsial infections. The test detects anti-rickettsial antibodies that cross-react with O antigens of certain nonmotile strains of Proteus. In this test, nonmotile strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K are used as antigens. The Weil–Felix test becomes positive 10–20 days after infection.

  • Sera from epidemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and weakly agglutinates with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from endemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and may weakly agglutinate with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from scrub typhus agglutinates with OX K antigen.
  • Weil–Felix test is negative or weakly reactive in Brill–Zinsser disease.

Weil–Felix test in rickettsial diseases:

Epidemic typhus +++ +  -
Brill–Zinsser disease +/-  -  -
Endemic typhus +++ +/-  -
Spotted fever ++ ++  -
Scrub typhus  -  - +++

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman who had a long history of dyspnoea, chronic cough, and wheezing passed away due to respiratory failure following pneumonia. She was a smoker. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a gross specimen of lung with panacinar emphysema. The clinical scenario and image is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the entire acinus is enlarged from the level of respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.

α1-antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes.

Other options- 

Option A: Absent dynein arm causes primary ciliary dyskinesia. 

Option B: Mutation in the CFTR gene causes cystic fibrosis. Both the above conditions lead to bronchiectasis.

Option D: Antibodies against type 4 collagen cause Goodpasture syndrome which leads to pulmonary hemorrhage and nephritis.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar

  • Lower lobes of lung

  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal

  • Subpleural region

  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular

  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with itchy papules over the face, neck, and V area of the chest for the last 3 years which are exacerbated in summers and improved in winters. What is the type of hypersensitivity associated with this disease process?
questions.solution:
The given history points towards photoallergic contact dermatitis and is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

The dermatitis is localized to exposed areas of the skin, usually with well‐demarcated margins where the skin is not covered by clothing, for example at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, below the end of sleeves on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles below the trouser legs. Photo allergic contact dermatitis spares the skin behind the earlobe (Wilkinson’s triangle) since it is a photo-protected site.

Photopatch test: The main clinical indication includes the investigation of patients with eczematous rashes predominantly affecting light‐exposed sites and a history of worsening following sun exposure. Application of the allergens is done similar to conventional patch tests, except that they must be applied in duplicate – one set is irradiated and the other (the control) is not. Usually, the two sets of tests are applied on either side of the vertebral column at the same level. A positive reaction on the irradiated side only is an indication of photoallergy.

Image: Photopatch test results- Reaction after exposure to UVA only.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) treated by dialysis as shown below, presents with a dry cough and breathlessness. Her chest X-ray revealed a hydrothorax on the right. Which of the following pleural fluid findings is most likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
The given image shows peritoneal dialysis and the clinical scenario points toward a diagnosis of transudative pleural effusion which is a complication of peritoneal dialysis. Pleural fluid LDH/ serum LDH < 0.4 is seen in transudative pleural effusion. 

A sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure opens communication between the abdomen and the thorax, allowing PD fluid to leak into the thorax. Hydrothorax frequently presents as respiratory distress, particularly dyspnea or shortness of breath.

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

In peritoneal dialysis(PD), the peritoneum itself acts as a semipermeable membrane. A peritoneal catheter is used to infuse the fluid into the cavity. 1.5–3 L of dialysis fluid is infused into the peritoneal cavity. It is allowed to dwell for a set period of time usually 2–4 hours to allow for the removal of metabolic waste products. The dialysis fluid contains osmotically active agents such as glucose or icodextrin.

Different types of peritoneal dialysis:

  • CAPD: Continous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis
  • CCPD: Continous cyclic peritoneal dialysis
  • NIDP: Nocturnal intermittent peritoneal dialysis

The major difference between the dialysate used for peritoneal and hemodialysis is that the hypertonicity of peritoneal dialysis solution drives solute and fluid removal, whereas solute removal in hemodialysis depends on concentration gradient and requires a transmembrane pressure. 

The following image shows the process of peritoneal dialysis.

questions.text: Chest X-ray of a patient taken for suspicion of tuberculosis showed poor contrast. Which of the following can be done to increase the contrast of the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The contrast of an X-ray can be increased by decreasing the kilovoltage peak.

Kilovoltage peak(kVp) is the difference in potential applied to the X-ray tube.

kVp ∝ Penetration
             Contrast
X-ray image quality increases with increase in kVp but the contrast decreases.

Milliampere seconds(mAs) is a unit representing the amount of current passed through the X-ray tube. Increasing the mAs can indirectly affect contrast by improving the signal-to-noise ratio.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis?
  1. Pyruvate carboxylase
  2. Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase
  3. Hexokinase
  4. Pyruvate kinase
  5. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are enzymes used in gluconeogenesis. These enzymes catalyze irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis.

Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are 2 metabolic pathways in opposite directions (glucose being the substrate and product respectively). The reversible enzymes are common in both pathways. But a few reactions are not reversible in glycolysis. So a different pathway is used or a different enzyme is used by the body to make the reactions feasible.

At the start of gluconeogenesis, pyruvate carboxylase (Option 1) catalyzes the synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate following which phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase converts it to phosphoenolpyruvate (not phosphoenol pyruvate kinase as in Option 2). Alternatively, at the end of glycolysis, the reverse of this reaction occurs in a single step catalyzed by pyruvate kinase (Option 4).

At the end of gluconeogenesis, glucose 6 phosphatase (Option 5) converts glucose-1-phosphate to free glucose and is an irreversible process. Alternatively, glycolysis starts with the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate by hexokinase (Option 3).

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to have jaundice. His stools are yellow and his urine is pale straw yellow-colored. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast milk jaundice is uncommon and is seen in exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 3-4 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain pregnanediol and β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Options A and D- Biliary atresia and neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option B- Erythroblastosis fetalis have unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with a history of high-grade fever for the last 5 days. She was recently diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. On examination, a new regurgitant murmur is heard and an echocardiogram shows the presence of a mass on the mitral valve. When her hands were examined, the following lesions were seen which were painful. What are these lesions known as?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient would be infective endocarditis (IE). The image shows erythematous, nodular lesions located in the pads of the fingers which are painful. These are known as Osler nodes. It occurs due to immune complex deposition and vasculitis.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes -are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Splenic abscess
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual hemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms
  • Splenomegaly

Below image- Janeway lesions (Option A)

Below image- Roth Spots (Option C)

The Woronoff ring (Option D) is the clear peripheral zone around the plaques, seen in psoriasis.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.
