questions.text: Which of the following drugs for insomnia can be given late at night?
questions.solution:
Out of the given drugs, zaleplon can be administered late at night, within a few hours of the anticipated rising time.

The Z compounds are efficacious hypnotics because due to agonist effects at the GABAA receptor, at the same site where the benzodiazepines bind. However, compared to benzodiazepines, Z compounds have less anticonvulsant and muscle relaxant action. Z compounds are now the preferred drugs for insomnia.

Although initially touted to have no abuse potential and no dependence, post-marketing surveillance of these drugs has shown tolerance and physical dependence can be seen, especially if these drugs are being taken in large doses. Overdose with Z compounds presents similarly to benzodiazepine overdose, and can be treated with flumazenil. 

The Z compounds include zolpidem, zaleplon, zopiclone, and eszopiclone. Zaleplon and zolpidem are used for treating sleep-onset insomnia. Zolpidem has a half-life of about 2 hours, so it is able to cover the entire duration of sleep. It is approved for use at bedtime only. Zaleplon has a shorter half-life of 1 hour, so it can be given safely even late at night. Zaleplon does not have any residual sedation or delayed reaction time in the morning, while zolpidem has been associated with these findings.

Zopiclone and eszopiclone are used for the long-term management of insomnia and sleep maintenance. 

Lorazepam (option B) is benzodiazepine. It causes a decrease in the sleep latency and the number of awakenings. The time spent in REM sleep is shorter, but the number of REM cycles is increased. Benzodiazepines increase the total sleep time, which might lead to the patient feeling sleepy even in the morning. Hence, these drugs cannot be used late at night.

Diphenhydramine (option D) is an anti-histaminic that can also be used for the treatment of insomnia. However, because of its excessive sedation even at daytime and anticholinergic side effects, Z compounds are the preferred drugs.

questions.text: What is the unit of study in a cohort study?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies have individuals as the unit of study.

Types of epidemiological studies:

  • Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.
    1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population.
    2. Analytical studies - go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables.
      • Ecological studies
      • Cross-sectional studies
      • Case-control studies
      • Cohort studies

All analytical studies have individuals as the unit of study, except ecological study which has population as the unit of study.

  • Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences.
    1. Randomized controlled trials(RCT) - Patients are the unit of study
    2. Field trials - healthy people are the unit of study
    3. Community trials - Community is the unit of study

questions.text: All the following statements regarding first-order kinetics are true except?

choices.text: Rate of elimination is proportional to plasma conc
Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

questions.solution:
In first order kinetics, constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time.

Difference Between First and Zero Order Kinetics

First Order Kinetics (Flow limited elimination) Zero Order Kinetics (Capacity limited elimination)
The rate of elimination is directly proportional to the drug concentration in the plasma The rate of elimination remains constant irrespective of drug concentration in the plasma
Clearance remains constant Clearance decreases with increase in plasma concentration of the drug
A constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in unit time. A constant amount of the drug is eliminated in unit time.
t½ remains constant t½ increases with dose

Ethanol follows zero-order kinetics. Drugs such as warfarin, phenytoin, theophylline, and tolbutamide also follow zero-order kinetics.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 39-year-old man who was being evaluated for backache is given below. What is the earliest sign that would be seen radiographically in this condition?

choices.text: Erosion and fuzziness of sacroiliac joints

questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a bamboo spine which is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis, and erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints is the first sign to appear radiographically in ankylosing spondylitis.

Important X-ray features of ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints:

  • Sacroiliitis is usually the first manifestation and is bilateral and symmetrical.
  • Cardinal sign/earliest sign is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Later- periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint.

Vertebral changes: 

  • Early spondylitis is characterized by small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis: Romanus lesions of the spine (Shiny corner sign)
  • Squaring of vertebral bodies or flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the spine due to inflammatory resorption of the bone.
  • Later signs are ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs producing syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae.
  • Bamboo spine appearance is due to bridging at several vertebral levels.
  • Linear ossification along the central spine; representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a Dagger sign appearance on frontal radiographs.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presented to the emergency room within two hours of sudden onset of weakness of the right side. On examination, she had global aphasia, right facial droop, and right hemiplegia. CT angiography showed a left middle cerebral artery occlusion. Which of the following is the next best management?

MCA- Middle cerebral artery
questions.solution:
The given features of hemiparesis and facial drooping with aphasia are suggestive of a stroke. CT angiography confirms the diagnosis. The next best step of management is thrombolysis in this case.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and to improve blood flow. Intravenous alteplase has been the mainstay of thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke. 

Indications for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke:

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • The onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <4.5 hours
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of MCA territory 
  • Age of the patient >18 years

Contraindications for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke:

  • Sustained blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment 
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

However, mechanical thrombectomy is beneficial as well for acute ischemic stroke due to a proximal large artery occlusion in the anterior circulation or in patients who are ineligible for thrombolysis.

Management of stroke:

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. It can identify extra parenchymal hemorrhages, subarachnoid hemorrhages, neoplasms, abscesses, and other conditions that can mimic stroke. However, in the case of ischemic stroke, the CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. 

Imaging modalities that can be useful in the early identification of stroke are diffusion-weighted imaging, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR), and MR perfusion studies using gadolinium contrast.

Treatment of acute ischemic stroke:

Initial treatment: Check for the patient's pulse rate, blood pressure, temperature, and glucose levels. Treat hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever if present. Maintain the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation.

Blood pressure should be reduced acutely if :

  • Blood pressure > 220/120 mmHg
  • There is malignant hypertension
  • There is concomitant myocardial ischemia
  • Blood pressure is > 185/110 mmHg and the patient is being planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 180mg/dL and 60mg/dL.

Ischemia can result in edema which peaks on the second or third day and can lead to a mass effect for around 10 days. Therefore, intravenous mannitol should be started and water restriction should be advised for the patients.

Specific measures:

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 325 mg should be started within 24-48 hours of acute ischemic stroke. It is also continued as an adjunct therapy after intravenous thrombolysis.

Routine use of heparin and other oral anticoagulants is not recommended in patients with ischemic stroke because they can increase the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. They can be used if the patient is bedridden, in order to prevent deep vein thrombosis. (Option B)

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries.

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: A patient with a history of humerus fracture treated with open reduction and internal fixation 9 months back presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent pain at the fracture site. On examination, there was mobility at the fracture site. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Bone scan revealed cold spots. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of open reduction and internal fixation for a humerus fracture with the X-ray showing a persistent fracture line and cold spots on the bone scan is suggestive of atrophic nonunion.

Atrophic nonunion is characterized by the presence of a persistent fracture line with no callus formation despite adequate fixation at the fracture site. This lack of healing response can be due to open fracture injuries, subsequent surgical treatment, or host factors like diabetes, smoking, etc. Clinical features in a case of nonunion include persistent pain at the fracture site, pain on stressing the fracture, and mobility at the fracture site. A bone scan is used to differentiate atrophic nonunion from oligotrophic nonunion. Bone scan shows hot spots in oligotrophic nonunion whereas it shows cold spots in atrophic nonunion. Management includes autologous bone grafting or bone morphogenic protein to stimulate fracture healing.

Based on the biological activity at the fracture site, non-union can be classified as:

  • Atrophic nonunion: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction. It is differentiated from an atrophic nonunion by a bone scan. There will be increased uptake in oligotrophic nonunion, but an atrophic nonunion would be relatively cold on the bone scan.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion: These fractures have an adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation that doesn't bridge the fracture site. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with onychomycosis was prescribed terbinafine. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene leading to impaired ergosterol synthesis
Chelation of trivalent metal ions causing inhibition of metal-dependent enzymes

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of terbinafine is the inhibition of the enzyme squalene epoxidase and thus impairing ergosterol synthesis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. This is an early step in the synthesis of ergosterol, an important constituent of the fungal cell membrane. Terbinafine is an inhibitor of this enzyme. This results in the accumulation of squalene, which is toxic to the organism.

Flucytosine is converted inside the fungal cells to FdUMP and FUTP which inhibit DNA and RNA synthesis respectively (option A). Flucytosine shows synergy with amphotericin B and is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

Griseofulvin disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting the microtubule function (option C). Griseofulvin is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children.

Ciclopirox olamine is a broad-spectrum fungicidal agent that acts by chelating trivalent metal cations (option D) which leads to inhibition of the metal-dependent enzyme that degrades free radicals in the fungal cell. It is available as a nail lacquer formulation in the treatment of onychomycosis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which of the following virus is known as delta virus?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is called the delta virus. It is a defective RNA virus, which depends on hepatitis B virus (HBV) for its replication. It has no independent existence.

Two types of infection may occur:  

  • Co-infection: Acute HDV and HBV infections occur simultaneously.
  • Super-infection: Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harboring HBV. This most often leads to chronic hepatitis.

Note: While COVID has a delta variant, it is not called the delta virus.

questions.text: What is the site of origin and type of stridor seen in a condition characterized by omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx (marked as A) which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in patients with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
Sunitinib is approved for the treatment of GIST in patients who have developed resistance to imatinib.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation associated with GIST is the c-KIT gene mutation. Most of the tumors are found in the stomach, but they can arise from any part of the GIT. Symptoms of GIST include pain abdomen, nausea, vomiting, and hematemesis. GIST can also present as an asymptomatic mass per abdomen.

They are diagnosed incidentally on endoscopy and can be confirmed by targeted biopsy by endoscopic ultrasound. The primary mode of treatment is surgical resection. Any GIST >2 cm in size must be resected surgically. In case the tumor is locally advanced, pre-operative imatinib can be given to the patients to reduce the tumor burden and enable complete resection. While smaller tumors can be treated by wedge resection, larger tumors may require gastrectomy or duodenectomy. Tumors >5 cm in size are considered to have metastatic potential and such patients should continue to receive imatinib after surgery as well.

Other options:

Option A: Sorafenib is an intracellular inhibitor of multiple kinases used in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option C: Vandetanib is an intracellular inhibitor of VEGFRs and EGFR family that is used in unresectable or metastatic medullary thyroid cancer.

Option D: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to VEGF and is used in multiple cancer regimens, including in metastatic colorectal cancer. Intravitreal injection of bevacizumab is also used in the wet type of age-related macular degeneration.

Related Pearl: Indications for Imatinib

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The level of amylase does not correlate with the severity of acute pancreatitis.

The diagnosis of acute pancreatitis can be made by a serum amylase level that is three-times higher than normal. However, the half-life of amylase is short, which means that the levels might be normal in patients who present to the hospital late. Serum lipase is a more sensitive and specific test than amylase.

It is extremely important to identify patients who have severe acute pancreatitis because they require more aggressive management. Many prognostic scores have been used for this purpose. The Ranson score is the one most commonly used and is given below. Severe pancreatitis is diagnosed if three or more factors in the Ranson score are present. The main advantage of the Ranson score is that the patient's condition is assessed at the time of admission and again at 48 hours following admission.

questions.text: A patient was started on ticagrelor following coronary angioplasty. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ticagrelor is a reversible antagonist of P2Y12 receptor.

Injury to the vessel wall exposes the subendothelial collagen and causes platelets to adhere and activate at the site. Activated platelets release ADP, which binds to P2Y12 receptors on other platelets in the circulation and causes their activation. This can cause amplifying cycles of clot formation and complete occlusion of the blood vessels. This is especially dangerous in patients with atherosclerotic plaques in the coronary arteries. Any acute plaque change, such as ulceration, can lead to thrombosis and acute coronary syndromes. 

This is where anti-platelet drugs such as P2Y12 inhibitors come in. P2Y12 inhibitors include clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor and cangrelor. Some of the features of these drugs are summarized below:

Clopidogrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

It is a prodrug; requires activation by CYP 2C19 to work.

Blocks platelet aggregation for the entire lifetime of platelets

PPIs such as omeprazole and pantoprazole inhibit CYP 2C19, thus reducing the formation of active metabolite of clopidogrel and leading to therapeutic failure.
Prasugrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral It has a more rapid onset of action compared to clopidogrel.
Ticagrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

More rapid onset and offset of action compared to clopidogrel.

Associated with dyspnea and higher risk of intracranial bleeding; contraindicated in patients with history of intracranial bleeding.
Cangrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, intravenous Action begins within minutes and lasts for one hour following stoppage of the drug.

questions.text: A patient suffering from a methamphetamine use disorder has increased activity of the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Methamphetamine is a psychostimulant that increases the activity and expression of tyrosine hydroxylase. This causes an increase in the monoamine neurotransmitters including dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

Catecholamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine) are synthesized from tyrosine in the adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells). Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme that catalyzes the hydroxylation of tyrosine to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

The conversion of tyrosine to epinephrine occurs via four sequential steps:

  1. Ring hydroxylation of tyrosine to DOPA: Tyrosine hydroxylase
  2. Decarboxylation of DOPA to dopamine: DOPA decarboxylase
  3. Side-chain hydroxylation of dopamine to form: Dopamine β-hydroxylase
  4. N-methylation of norepinephrine to form epinephrine: Phenylethanolamine-N-Methyltransferase (PNMT)

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented to the OPD with purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins. Identify the lesion shown below that was found on the oral mucosa of this patient.
questions.solution:
Purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins are suggestive of Lichen planus. White streaks forming a lacework in the buccal mucosa, as seen in the image, is a characteristic feature of lichen planus known as Wickham’s striae.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. The primary lesions of lichen planus are described by the characteristic "6 Ps": planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques. These well-defined areas of purple-coloured, itchy, flat-topped papules may be with interspersed lacy white lines known as Wickham's striae. It may present with mucous membrane lesions in the absence of skin lesions, commonly involving the tongue and buccal mucosa.

Atrophy may mimic Wickham’s striae and leukoplakia, frictional keratosis and oral lichenoid eruptions are differentials. It must also be differentiated from erythroplakia and erythroleukoplakia by biopsy.

Other options:

Option 2: Hairy leukoplakia is a distinct oral lesion on the lateral border of the tongue caused by EBV that typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. It appears as white, confluent patches of fluffy or hairy, hyperkeratotic thickenings, almost always on the lateral border of the tongue. Unlike Candida-caused oral thrush, the lesion cannot be rubbed away.

Option 3: Frictional keratosis is caused by chronic irritation, particular lifestyle habits or infective agents. 

Option 4: Oral lichenoid eruptions are due to chrome/cobalt prosthesis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented to the OPD with complains of pain in her right wrist joint and deformity following a fall on an outstretched hand. Her wrist X-rays shows dorsal and lateral displacement of the fractured fragment. Which of the following deformity can be seen in this case on clinical examination?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray features and history of fall on an outstretched hand are features suggestive of Colles' fracture. Dinner fork deformity is seen in Colles' fracture. 

Dinner fork deformity results due to the malunion. There may be a limitation of wrist movement and forearm rotation. All the cases of malunited Colles' fracture are not treated.If there is a severe deformity or an impairment of function then osteotomy is performed and malunion is corrected.

Colles' fracture occurs at the distal end of the radius, at the cortico-cancellous junction. The distal fragment shows dorsal displacement, dorsal tilt, lateral displacement and lateral tilt. This fracture is particularly common in post-menopausal women because of osteoporosis. The patient presents with pain and swelling of the wrist. On examination, there is classic dinner fork deformity. 

Undisplaced Colles' fractures are managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast. The technique of reduction of Colles' fracture is as follows:

  • Disimpaction of the fracture fragments by longitudinal traction against counter traction provided by the assistant. 
  • The distal fragment is then pressed into palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation.
  • The patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.
  • A Colles' cast is then applied, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, with the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. 

Other options

Option B: Garden spade deformity is seen in Smith's fracture.

Option C: Swan neck deformity is seen in hyperextension of proximal interphalangeal joint(PIP) and flexion of distal interphalangeal joint. Seen in Rheumatoid arthritis. 

Option D: Sprengel's deformity is a rare congenital condition in which the scapula is too high on one side of the body.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient complains that he feels he is no longer in control of his body and thoughts. He says he hears his own thoughts aloud a short time after thinking them, for the last two years. He stopped going to college 6 months ago because he feels everyone can hear his thoughts and know what he is thinking all the time. Examination reveals disorganized speech. He has no history of drug abuse. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of loss of control of body and thoughts, thought broadcasting, disorganized speech and delusions is suggestive of schizophrenia.

The loss of control of the body and thoughts is known as the passivity phenomenon. The patient being able to hear his thought for the last two years is known as thought echo which is a form of auditory hallucination. The feeling that everyone can hear his thoughts is called thought broadcasting which is a disorder of thought process. All these signs point towards the diagnosis of schizophrenia.

Schizophrenia is a disorder comprised of a group of characteristic symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, negative symptoms, disorganized lifestyle, and continuous signs of these disturbances for at least 6 months. 

Dopamine excess is believed to play an important role in the development of the disease. A genetic component is also suspected to be contributory.

The symptoms are mainly divided into positive or negative symptoms. The positive symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, and motor disturbances. The negative symptoms include anhedonia, alogia, flattening of affect, apathy, and poverty of speech.

DSM-5 criteria for schizophrenia:

A. ≥2 of the following symptoms of which at least one of these is either 1, 2, or 3:

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganized speech
  4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
  5. Negative symptoms

B. Level of functioning in one or more major areas of functioning such as work or social life is markedly below the level it used to be before the onset of the disturbance.

C. Continuous signs of disturbance for at least 6 months.

D. Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out.

E. Disturbance cannot be explained by substance abuse or any other medical condition.

F. If there is a positive history of autism spectrum disorder or a communication disorder since childhood, diagnosis of schizophrenia is made only if the delusions or hallucinations are very prominent.

Anti-psychotics are the mainstay of treatment. They mainly act by antagonizing the postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the brain. Psychosocial therapy also plays an important role and can augment clinical improvement. Some cases may require short stays at the hospital either for patient safety or for stabilization of medications.

There are several factors that affect the prognosis of schizophrenia:

Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Late/acute onset Early/insidious onset
Mood disorder symptoms Withdrawn, autistic behavior
Family history of mood disorders  Family history of schizophrenia
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Married Single, divorced or widowed
  Neurological signs and symptoms
  Many relapses

Other options:

Option A- Schizoaffective disorder can be diagnosed when manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with major symptoms of schizophrenia. 

Option B- Schizophreniform disorder is described as acute psychiatric symptoms as in schizophrenia that were reactive and occurred in persons with relatively normal personalities that last at least 1 month but less than 6 months. 

Option D- Delusional disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more non-bizarre delusions (false beliefs that are possible but not true) lasting for at least one month. There is no significant impairment in functioning apart from the delusions.

questions.text: Cyclin D1 is over-expressed in which of the following lymphomas?
questions.solution:
Cyclin D1 is over-expressed in Mantle cell lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm in which tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells surrounding the germinal center. Translocation (11;14) causes overexpression of cyclin D1 proto-oncogene.

It usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life. Male patients are commonly affected.  The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. They may also have hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Mucosal involvement produces polyps-like lesions in the small intestine or colon. This is called lymphomatoid polyposis.

On histopathology, the tumors cells may be spread diffusely across the node or may surround the germinal centers to give a nodular appearance. The lymphocytes are small in size and contain a deeply cleaved nucleus (resemble centrocytes). This picture is similar to follicular lymphoma. However, follicular lymphoma also contains large cells resembling centroblasts. This feature can be used to differentiate mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD5, and surface immunoglobulins (Ig). They are negative for CD23. In cases, where cyclin D1 is negative, SOX11 marker can be used to identify this lymphoma. 

Other options-

Option A: Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. Most follicular lymphomas have characteristic (14:18) translocation, leading to overexpression of BCL2. Lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern.

Option B: Hodgkin's lymphoma arises in a single lymph node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells which are CD 15+ and CD30+

Option D: Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

questions.text: An elderly man complains of inability to extend the fingers of his left hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his elbow and wrist, but cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints of the hand. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of radial nerve injury. The structure marked as 4 is the radial nerve. It can be seen dividing into the posterior interosseous nerve and the superficial radial nerve in the elbow.

The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It mainly supplies the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Branches of the radial nerve:

  • In the axilla and the radial groove- It supplies the triceps muscles.
  • Proximal to the lateral epicondyle- nerve to brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus

At the tip of the lateral epicondyle, the nerve divides into the superficial radial nerve and posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseus nerve supplies the supinator, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, abductor pollicis longus, and extensor pollicis brevis. 

The superficial branch of the radial nerve supplies the skin over the anatomical snuffbox, lateral half of the dorsum of hand, and lateral 2 1⁄2 digits till their distal interphalangeal joints

Radial nerve injuries:

  • Very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, it results in loss of extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand.
  • In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.
  • Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice that the jugular venous pressure (JVP) does not fall during inspiration and in fact, shows a paradoxical rise. Which of the following clinical conditions is least likely to be associated with the clinical finding seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy. 

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure, the JVP falls. When there is an impairment in the filling or expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, the blood backs up in the jugular veins. The backpressure causes an elevation or a failure in the appropriate fall in JVP during inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

It is also a common, isolated finding in patients after cardiac surgery without other hemodynamic abnormalities.

questions.text: What is the type of joint found in the manubriosternum?
questions.solution:
The Manubriosternal joint is a secondary cartilaginous joint. 

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

  • Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. Example: 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis/primary cartilaginous joints. Example: costochondral joints
  • Symphysis/secondary cartilaginous joints. Example: Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these helps the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

Secondary cartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of a fibrocartilaginous disc that connects the articular surfaces, which are covered by a thin layer of hyaline cartilage. These joints are considered permanent. Examples of secondary cartilaginous joints include the symphysis pubis, the manubriosternal joint, and the intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies.

Synchondrosis refers to the primary cartilaginous joints in which the advancing areas of ossification are separated by hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints and are associated with growth. Hyaline cartilage has the ability to ossify with age, thus making these joints undergo synostosis once the growth is complete. An example of this type of joint is the epiphyseal plate. 

Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. E.g, 1st sternocostal joint

Syndesmosis refers to a type of joint where bones are connected by true fibrous tissue. In some cases, this connection is established through an interosseous ligament, as seen in the tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis. In other instances, the connection is formed by a dense fibrous membrane, particularly in the posterior region of the sacroiliac joint.

questions.text: Anxious parents complain to the police that their daughter was allegedly kidnapped by a man. When police found her and produced her before the court she said she is a major and is married to the man. An X-ray image of her hand is given below. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of the hand shows the appearance of pisiform (more than 10 years) but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal (less than 17 years). Among the given options, the likely age of the girl is <17 years and she is not as major.

The base of 1st metacarpal appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is >15 years. 

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

The appearance of ossification centers of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 2-3 months
  • Hamate:  2 months
  • Triquetral: 3 years
  • Lunate: 4 years
  • Scaphoid: 5 years
  • Trapezium: 6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: A G2P1 female with 5 months of gestation comes to the OPD with a complaint as shown in the picture. On examination, her BP is 130/90 mmHg. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of edema and bed rest is the appropriate treatment for women having edema in pregnancy.

The cause of physiological edema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of the physiological edema:

  • Slight degree (ankle edema)
  • Usually confined to one leg, more on the right
  • Unassociated with any other features of preeclampsia or proteinuria
  • Disappears on rest alone
  • Other pathologies of cardiac, renal, and hematological are absent.

Note: For this patient to qualify for preeclampsia, she should have blood pressure that exceeds 140/90 mm Hg or greater and should be documented on two occasions, at least four hours apart.

questions.text: Which of the following does not require therapeutic drug monitoring?

choices.text: A drug with narrow therapeutic index
A drug whose effect lasts longer than the drug itself
A toxic drug used in a patient with renal failure
A drug which shows significant individual variations in pharmacokinetics

questions.solution:
Therapeutic dose monitoring (TDM) is not required for a drug whose effects last longer than the drug itself.

TDM refers to measuring the plasma concentration of the drug at fixed intervals to determine the individual bioavailability and clearance, and then adjust the dose of the drug accordingly.

TDM is of no value for:

  • Drugs whose response is easily measurable, such as antihypertensives and anti-diabetic drugs
  • Drugs that are activated in the body, such as Levodopa
  • Drugs whose effects last longer than the drug itself (hit-and-run drugs), such as proton-pump inhibitors
  • Drugs with irreversible action, such as organophosphorus compounds and phenoxybenzamine

TDM is particularly useful for:

  • Drugs with low safety margin, such as digoxin and anticonvulsants
  • Drugs with large individual variations, such as lithium and anti-depressants
  • Potentially toxic drugs in patients of renal failure, such as aminoglycosides and vancomycin
  • Poisoning cases
  • To check patient compliance with the drug

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

FG- Fresh gas

questions.solution:
The above image shows Mapleson’s Type B breathing circuit. There is the presence of a corrugated tube, and the fresh gas flow and valve are located near the patient.

Mapleson’s breathing systems are used for delivering oxygen and anesthetic agents and eliminating carbon dioxide during anesthesia. They consist of different components: Fresh gas flow, reservoir bag, breathing tubes, expiratory valve, and patient connection.

There are six types of Mapleson’s circuits denoted by A – F.

Other options:

Option A - In Mapleson type A circuits, the fresh gas flow enters through the opposite end of the circuit near the reservoir bag. They have a spring-loaded pop-off valve located near the patient. It is the most efficient for spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Type C Mapleson circuits are similar to Type B circuits, but they do not have the corrugated tube.

Option D - Type D  circuits have fresh gas flow is near the patient end, and excess gas is vented off at the opposite end of the circuit. It is the most efficient for controlled ventilation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ophthalmology outpatient clinic with complaints of redness, pain, and watering of the left eye for the past two days. He also complained of difficulty in vision. A careful slit-lamp examination revealed the following finding in the anterior chamber. Which of the following is true regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail
Sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.
Unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.
Sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of an adult worm of Loa Loa in the anterior chamber of the eye. The microfilariae of Loa loa are sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Loiasis is a skin and eye disease caused by the nematode worm Loa loa. Humans contract this disease through the bite of a deer fly or mango fly, the vectors for Loa loa. The adult filarial worm migrates throughout the subcutaneous tissues of humans. Subconjunctival migration of an adult worm to the eyes can occur frequently and is thus called the African eye worm. It causes painless edema of the eyelids and proptosis. Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere.

The microfilaria of Loa loa has diurnal periodicity and is usually found in day blood samples. It is known to migrate to the skin and other tissues at night, which causes itchiness commonly reported in ‘night guards’ infested with the disease. Loiasis is diagnosed by:

  • Characteristic history and presentation with eosinophilia, and elevated levels of antifilarial antibodies, particularly in travelers to an endemic region
  • Detection of microfilariae in the peripheral blood 
  • Isolation of the adult worm from the eye or a subcutaneous biopsy from a swelling 
  • PCR-based assays for the detection of L. loa DNA in blood

Onchocerciasis caused by Onchocerca volvulus is a differential diagnosis in this case. 

  • Ocular onchocerciasis may affect any part of the eyeball and may cause keratitis, iridocyclitis, choroiditis, glaucoma, and optic neuritis and cause blindness (commonly known as ‘river blindness’). Loa loa, on the other hand, mainly involves subconjunctival tissues.
  • Onchocerca is usually smaller in size than Loa loa.
  • The adult worm of Onchocerca is found in subcutaneous nodules while the microfilariae may be seen in the skin and eyes. The adult worm of Loa loa is seen in the conjunctiva and connective tissue while microfilariae are found in the blood.
  • The pattern of microfilaraemia in onchocerciasis is opposite to that in Loa loa. It is nonperiodic where the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. 
  • The microfilariae are unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei. 

Other options:

Option A: A sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail is characteristic of Brugia malayi and it causes filariasis.

Option D: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei and it causes filariasis.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text:
An elderly woman complains of breathlessness which worsens on lying down. There is bilateral pitting pedal edema and bibasilar crepitations on auscultation. Which of the following findings can be present in this patient?

BNP: B-type natriuretic peptide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heart failure, and hyperaldosteronism is associated with it.

Decreased cardiac output in heart failure causes baroreceptor dysfunction and decreased inhibitory signals to the vasomotor center (VMC). Activation of VMC leads to generalized increased sympathetic tone (option C) in the body. Furthermore, sympathetic stimulation of the kidney leads to decreased renal blood flow (option D) and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Increased aldosterone causes increased Na+ and water absorption, peripheral vasoconstriction, and myocyte hypertrophy and fibrosis (remodeling).

There is an increase in hormones like atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP), PGE1, PGI2, bradykinin, and nitric oxide. ANP and BNP are released from the atria and ventricles respectively and cause systemic and pulmonary vasodilation, increased sodium and water excretion, and inhibition of the RAAS.

Other conditions that cause hyperaldosteronism include:

  • Cirrhosis and nephrotic syndrome (secondary hyperaldosteronism)
  • High potassium intake
  • Low sodium intake

questions.solution:
The given image is of a hysterosalpingogram showing the contrast dye filling an irregulary shaped edometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance. Hence, it is Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion.

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected:

  • Radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) offers information regarding both uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency.
  • Saline infusion sonography can be performed alternative to HSG.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.
